Text

THERE were once [four children who spent [their]273-four children who spent their summer holidays in a white house , happily situated between a sandpit and a chalkpit summer holidays in [a white house]274-a white house , happily situated between [a sandpit and a chalkpit]275-a sandpit and a chalkpit]273-four children who spent their summer holidays in a white house , happily situated between a sandpit and a chalkpit . One day [they]273-four children who spent their summer holidays in a white house , happily situated between a sandpit and a chalkpit had the good fortune to find in [the sandpit]276-the sandpit a strange creature . [Its]277-it eyes were on long horns like snail ’s eyes , and it could move them in and out like telescopes . [It]277-it had ears like a bat ’s ears , and [its]277-it tubby body was shaped like a spider ’s and covered with thick soft fur — and it had hands and feet like a monkey ’s . [It]277-it told [the children]278-the children — whose names were [Cyril]131-cyril , [Robert]132-robert , [Anthea]133-anthea , and [Jane]134-jane — that it was a Psammead or sand‐fairy . ( Psammead is pronounced [Sammy‐ad]135-sammy‐ad . ) [It]277-it was old , old , old , and its birthday was almost at the very beginning of everything . And it had been buried in [the sand]279-the sand for thousands of years . But it still kept its fairylikeness , and part of this fairylikeness was its power to give [people]280-people whatever [they]280-people wished for . [You]281-you know [fairies]282-fairies have always been able to do this . [Cyril]131-cyril , [Robert]132-robert , [Anthea]133-anthea , and [Jane]134-jane now found [their]278-the children wishes come true ; but , somehow , [they]278-the children never could think of just the right things to wish for , and [their]278-the children wishes sometimes turned out very oddly indeed . In the end [their]278-the children unwise wishings landed [them]278-the children in what [Robert]132-robert called “ a very tight place indeed , ”[132-robert] and [the Psammead]136-the psammead consented to help [them]278-the children out of [it]277-it in return for [their]278-the children promise never never to ask it to grant [them]278-the children any more wishes , and never to tell [anyone]283-anyone about it , because [it]136-the psammead did not want to be bothered to give wishes to [anyone]283-anyone ever any more . At the moment of parting [Jane]134-jane said politely — “ [I]134-jane wish [we]278-the children were going to see [you]136-the psammead again some day . ”[134-jane] And [the Psammead , touched by this friendly thought]285-the psammead , touched by this friendly thought , granted the wish . The book about all this is called “ [Five Children]2242-five children and [It]136-the psammead , ”[136-the psammead] and it ends up in a most tiresome way by saying — “ [The children]278-the children did see [the Psammead]136-the psammead again , but it was not in [the sandpit]276-the sandpit ; it was — but [I]136-the psammead must say no more — ”[136-the psammead] The reason that nothing more could be said was that [I]0-i had not then been able to find out exactly when and where [the children]278-the children met [the Psammead]136-the psammead again . Of course [I]0-i knew [they]278-the children would meet [it]136-the psammead , because it was a beast of its word , and when it said a thing would happen , that thing happened without fail . How different from [the people who tell [us]288-us about what weather it is going to be on Thursday next , in [London]2-london , [the South Coast]289-the south coast , and [Channel]3-channel]287-the people who tell us about what weather it is going to be on thursday next , in london , the south coast , and channel ! The summer holidays during which [the Psammead]136-the psammead had been found and the wishes given had been wonderful holidays in [the country]290-the country , and [the children]278-the children had the highest hopes of just such another holiday for the next summer . The winter holidays were beguiled by the wonderful happenings of “ The Phœnix and the Carpet , ”[278-the children] and the loss of these two treasures would have left [the children]278-the children in despair , but for the splendid hope of [their]278-the children next holiday in [the country]290-the country . [The world]294-the world , [they]278-the children felt , and indeed had some reason to feel , was full of wonderful things — and [they]278-the children were really the sort of people that wonderful things happen to . So [they]278-the children looked forward to the summer holiday ; but when it came everything was different , and very , very horrid . [Father]137-father had to go out to [Manchuria]4-manchuria to telegraph news about the war to the tiresome paper [he]137-father wrote for — the Daily Bellower , or something like that , was its name . And [Mother]138-mother , [poor dear Mother]138-mother , was away in [Madeira]5-madeira , because [she]138-mother had been very ill . And [The Lamb]295-the lamb — [I]0-i mean [the baby]296-the baby — was with [her]138-mother . And [Aunt Emma]139-aunt emma , who was [[Mother]297-mother ’s sister]298-mother ’s sister , had suddenly married [Uncle Reginald]140-uncle reginald , who was [[Father]137-father ’s brother]299-father ’s brother , and [they]300-they had gone to [China]6-china , which is much too far off for [you]301-you to expect to be asked to spend the holidays in , however fond [[your]301-you aunt]302-your aunt and [uncle]303-uncle may be of [you]301-you . So [the children]278-the children were left in the care of [old Nurse]305-old nurse , who lived in [Fitzroy Street]7-fitzroy street , near [the British Museum]306-the british museum , and though [she]305-old nurse was always very kind to [them]278-the children , and indeed spoiled [them]278-the children far more than would be good for [the most grown‐up of [us]308-us]307-the most grown‐up of us , [the four children]309-the four children felt perfectly wretched , and when [the cab]310-the cab had driven off with [Father]137-father and all [his]137-father boxes and guns and the sheepskin , with blankets and the aluminium mess‐kit inside it , the stoutest heart quailed , and [the girls]311-the girls broke down altogether , and sobbed in [each other]312-each other ’s arms , while [the boys]313-the boys each looked out of one of the long gloomy windows of [the parlour]314-the parlour , and tried to pretend that [no boy]315-no boy would be [such a muff as to cry]316-such a muff as to cry . [I]0-i hope [you]317-you notice that [they]309-the four children were not cowardly enough to cry till [[their]309-the four children Father]318-their father had gone ; [they]309-the four children knew [he]137-father had quite enough to upset [him]137-father without that . But when [he]137-father was gone [everyone]319-everyone felt as if it had been trying not to cry all [its]319-everyone life , and that it must cry now , if it died for it . So [they]309-the four children cried . Tea — with shrimps and watercress — cheered [them]309-the four children a little . The watercress was arranged in a hedge round a fat glass salt‐cellar , a tasteful device [they]309-the four children had never seen before . But it was not a cheerful meal . After tea [Anthea]133-anthea went up to [the room that had been [Father]137-father ’s]320-the room that had been father ’s , and when [she]133-anthea saw how dreadfully [he]137-father was n’t [there]321-there , and remembered how every minute was taking [him]137-father further and further from [her]133-anthea , and nearer and nearer to the guns of [the Russians]322-the russians , [she]133-anthea cried a little more . Then [she]133-anthea thought of [Mother]138-mother , ill and alone , and perhaps at that very moment wanting [a little girl]323-a little girl to put eau‐de‐cologne on [her]323-a little girl head , and make [her]323-a little girl sudden cups of tea , and [she]133-anthea cried more than ever . And then [she]133-anthea remembered what [Mother]138-mother had said , the night before [she]138-mother went away , about [Anthea]133-anthea being [the eldest girl]324-the eldest girl , and about trying to make [the others]325-the others happy , and things like that . So [she]133-anthea stopped crying , and thought instead . And when [she]133-anthea had thought as long as [she]133-anthea could bear [she]133-anthea washed [her]133-anthea face and combed [her]133-anthea hair , and went down to [the others]325-the others , trying [her]133-anthea best to look as though crying were an exercise [she]133-anthea had never even heard of . [She]133-anthea found [the parlour]314-the parlour in deepest gloom , hardly relieved at all by the efforts of [Robert]132-robert , who , to make the time pass , was pulling [Jane]134-jane ’s hair — not hard , but just enough to tease . “ Look here , ”[133-anthea] said [Anthea]133-anthea . “ Let ’s have a palaver . ”[133-anthea] This word dated from the awful day when [Cyril]131-cyril had carelessly wished that there were Red Indians in [England]8-england — and there had been . The word brought back memories of last summer holidays and [everyone]319-everyone groaned ; [they]319-everyone thought of [the white house]329-the white house with [the beautiful tangled garden]330-the beautiful tangled garden — late roses , asters , marigold , sweet mignonette , and feathery asparagus — of the wilderness which [someone]331-someone had once meant to make into [an orchard]332-an orchard , but which was now , as [Father]137-father said , “ five acres of thistles haunted by the ghosts of baby cherry‐trees . ”[137-father] [They]319-everyone thought of the view across [the valley]333-the valley , where [the lime‐kilns]334-the lime‐kilns looked like [[Aladdin]141-aladdin ’s palaces]335-aladdin ’s palaces in the sunshine , and [they]319-everyone thought of [[their]319-everyone own sandpit]336-their own sandpit , with [its]336-their own sandpit fringe of yellowy grasses and pale , stringy‐stalked wild flowers , and the little holes in the cliff that were [the little sandmartens ’ little front doors]337-the little sandmartens ’ little front doors . And [they]319-everyone thought of the free fresh air smelling of thyme and sweetbrier , and the scent of the wood‐smoke from [the cottages in [the lane]339-the lane]338-the cottages in the lane — and [they]319-everyone looked round [[old Nurse]142-old nurse ’s stuffy parlour]340-old nurse ’s stuffy parlour , and [Jane]134-jane said — “ Oh , how different it all is ! ”[134-jane] It was . [Old Nurse]142-old nurse had been in the habit of letting [lodgings]341-lodgings , till [Father]137-father gave [her]142-old nurse [the children]278-the children to take care of . And [[her]142-old nurse rooms]343-her rooms were furnished “ for letting . ”[142-old nurse] Now it is a very odd thing that [no one]344-no one ever seems to furnish [a room]345-a room “ for letting ”[346-one] in a bit the same way as [one]346-one would furnish [it]345-a room for living in . [This room]347-this room had heavy dark red stuff curtains — the colour that blood would not make a stain on — with coarse lace curtains inside . The carpet was yellow , and violet , with bits of grey and brown oilcloth in odd places . The fireplace had shavings and tinsel in it . There was a very varnished mahogany chiffonier , or sideboard , with a lock that would n’t act . There were hard chairs — far too many of them — with crochet antimacassars slipping off [their]319-everyone seats , all of which sloped the wrong way . The table wore a cloth of a cruel green colour with a yellow chain‐stitch pattern round it . Over the fireplace was a looking‐glass that made [you]348-you look much uglier than [you]348-you really were , however plain [you]348-you might be to begin with . Then there was a mantelboard with maroon plush and wool fringe that did not match the plush ; a dreary clock like a black marble tomb — it was silent as [the grave]349-the grave too , for it had long since forgotten how to tick . And there were painted glass vases that never had any flowers in , and a painted tambourine that [no one]344-no one ever played , and painted brackets with nothing on them . There were two books — [last December]143-last december ’s “ Bradshaw , ”[143-last december] and an odd volume of [Plumridge]144-plumridge ’s “ Commentary on [Thessalonians]9-thessalonians . ”[134-jane] There were — but [I]0-i can not dwell longer on this painful picture . It was indeed , as [Jane]134-jane said , very different . “ Let ’s have [a palaver]2245-a palaver , ”[133-anthea] said [Anthea]133-anthea again . “ What about ? ”[131-cyril] said [Cyril]131-cyril , yawning . “ There ’s nothing to have anything about , ”[132-robert] said [Robert]132-robert kicking the leg of the table miserably . “ [I]134-jane do n’t want to play , ”[134-jane] said [Jane]134-jane , and [her]134-jane tone was grumpy . [Anthea]133-anthea tried very hard not to be cross . [She]133-anthea succeeded . “ Look here , ”[133-anthea] [she]133-anthea said , “ do n’t think [I]133-anthea want to be preachy or a beast in any way , but [I]133-anthea want to what [Father]137-father calls define the situation . Do [you]131-cyril agree ? ”[133-anthea] “ Fire ahead , ”[131-cyril] said [Cyril]131-cyril without enthusiasm . “ Well , then . [We]2246-we all know the reason [we]2246-we ’re staying [here]2247-here is because [Nurse]142-old nurse could n’t leave [[her]142-old nurse house]2248-her house on account of [the poor learned gentleman on the top‐floor]2249-the poor learned gentleman on the top‐floor . And there was [no one else Father]2250-no one else father could entrust to take care of [us]2246-we — and [you]131-cyril know it ’s taken a lot of money , [Mother]138-mother ’s going to [Madeira]5-madeira to be made well . ”[134-jane] [Jane]134-jane sniffed miserably . “ Yes , [I]133-anthea know , ”[133-anthea] said [Anthea]133-anthea in a hurry , “ but do n’t let ’s think about how horrid it all is . [I]134-jane mean [we]2246-we ca n’t go to things that cost a lot , but [we]2246-we must do something . And [I]134-jane know there are heaps of things [you]131-cyril can see in [London]2-london without paying for them , and [I]134-jane thought [we]2246-we ’d go and see them . [We]2246-we are all quite old now , and [we]2246-we have n’t got [The Lamb]145-the lamb — ”[134-jane] [Jane]134-jane sniffed harder than before . “ [I]134-jane mean [no one]344-no one can say ‘ No ’ because of [him]145-the lamb , [dear pet]2252-dear pet . And [I]134-jane thought [we]2246-we must get [Nurse]142-old nurse to see how quite old [we]2246-we are , and let [us]2246-we go out by [ourselves]2246-we , or else [we]2246-we shall never have any sort of a time at all . And [I]134-jane vote [we]2246-we see everything there is , and let ’s begin by asking [Nurse]142-old nurse to give [us]2246-we some bits of bread and [we]2246-we ’ll go to [St James ’s Park]10-st james ’s park . There are ducks there , [I]134-jane know , [we]2246-we can feed [them]2253-them . Only [we]2246-we must make [Nurse]142-old nurse let [us]2246-we go by [ourselves]2246-we . ”[134-jane] “ Hurrah for liberty ! ”[132-robert] said [Robert]132-robert , “ but [she]142-old nurse wo n’t . ”[132-robert] “ Yes [she]142-old nurse will , ”[134-jane] said [Jane]134-jane unexpectedly . “ [I]134-jane thought about that this morning , and [I]134-jane asked [Father]137-father , and [he]137-father said yes ; and what ’s more [he]137-father told [old Nurse]142-old nurse [we]2246-we might , only [he]137-father said [we]2246-we must always say where [we]2246-we wanted to go , and if it was right [she]142-old nurse would let [us]2246-we . ”[134-jane] “ Three cheers for thoughtful [Jane]134-jane , ”[131-cyril] cried [Cyril]131-cyril , now roused at last from [his]131-cyril yawning despair . “ [I]131-cyril say , let ’s go now . ”[131-cyril] So [they]351-they went , [old Nurse]142-old nurse only begging [them]351-they to be careful of [crossings]352-crossings , and to ask [a policeman]353-a policeman to assist in the more difficult cases . But [they]351-they were used to crossings , for [they]351-they had lived in [Camden Town]11-camden town and knew [the [Kentish Town]12-kentish town Road]354-the kentish town road where [the trams]355-the trams rush up and down like mad at all hours of the day and night , and seem as though , if anything , [they]351-they would rather run over [you]356-you than not . [They]351-they had promised to be [home]357-home by dark , but it was July , so dark would be very late indeed , and long past bedtime . [They]351-they started to walk to [St James ’s Park]10-st james ’s park , and all [their]351-they pockets were stuffed with bits of bread and the crusts of toast , to feed the ducks with . [They]351-they started , [I]0-i repeat , but [they]351-they never got [there]321-there . Between [Fitzroy Street]7-fitzroy street and [St James ’s Park]10-st james ’s park there are [a great many streets]359-a great many streets , and , if [you]356-you go the right way [you]356-you will pass [a great many shops that [you]356-you can not possibly help stopping to look at]360-a great many shops that you can not possibly help stopping to look at . [The children]278-the children stopped to look at several with gold‐lace and beads and pictures and jewellery and dresses , and hats , and oysters and lobsters in [their]278-the children windows , and [their]278-the children sorrow did not seem nearly so impossible to bear as it had done in [the best parlour at [No . 300]363-no . 300 , [Fitzroy Street]7-fitzroy street]362-the best parlour at no . 300 , fitzroy street . Presently , by some wonderful chance turn of [Robert]132-robert ’s ( who had been voted [Captain]364-captain because [the girls]311-the girls thought it would be good for [him]132-robert — and indeed [he]132-robert thought so [himself]132-robert — and of course [Cyril]131-cyril could n’t vote against [him]132-robert because it would have looked like a mean jealousy ) , [they]278-the children came into [the little interesting criss‐crossy streets that held the most interesting shops of all]366-the little interesting criss‐crossy streets that held the most interesting shops of all — [the shops where live things were sold]367-the shops where live things were sold . There was [one shop window entirely filled with cages , and all sorts of beautiful birds in them]368-one shop window entirely filled with cages , and all sorts of beautiful birds in them . [The children]278-the children were delighted till [they]278-the children remembered how [they]278-the children had once wished for wings [themselves]278-the children , and had had [them]370-them — and then [they]278-the children felt how desperately unhappy anything with wings must be if it is shut up in a cage and not allowed to fly . “ It must be fairly beastly to be a bird in a cage , ”[131-cyril] said [Cyril]131-cyril . “ Come on ! ”[131-cyril] [They]278-the children went on , and [Cyril]131-cyril tried to think out a scheme for making [his]131-cyril fortune as a gold‐digger at [Klondyke]13-klondyke , and then buying all the caged birds in [the world]294-the world and setting [them]372-them free . Then [they]278-the children came to [a shop that sold cats]373-a shop that sold cats , but the cats were in [cages]374-cages , and [the children]278-the children could not help wishing [some one]376-some one would buy all the cats and put them on hearthrugs , which are the proper places for cats . And there was the dog‐shop , and that was not a happy thing to look at either , because all the dogs were chained or caged , and all the dogs , big and little , looked at [the four children]309-the four children with sad wistful eyes and wagged beseeching tails as if [they]278-the children were trying to say , “ Buy [me]309-the four children ! buy [me]309-the four children ! buy [me]309-the four children ! and let [me]309-the four children go for a walk with [you]309-the four children ; oh , do buy [me]309-the four children , and buy [[my]309-the four children poor brothers]2254-my poor brothers too ! Do ! do ! do ! ”[309-the four children] [They]309-the four children almost said , “ Do ! do ! do ! ”[309-the four children] plain to the ear , as [they]309-the four children whined ; all but [one big Irish terrier]378-one big irish terrier , and [he]378-one big irish terrier growled when [Jane]134-jane patted [him]378-one big irish terrier . “ Grrrrr , ”[378-one big irish terrier] [he]378-one big irish terrier seemed to say , as [he]378-one big irish terrier looked at [them]309-the four children from the back corner of [his]378-one big irish terrier eye—“You wo n’t buy [me]378-one big irish terrier . [Nobody]2255-nobody will — ever — [I]378-one big irish terrier shall die chained up — and [I]378-one big irish terrier do n’t know that [I]378-one big irish terrier care how soon it is , either ! ”[378-one big irish terrier] [I]0-i do n’t know that [the children]278-the children would have understood all this , only once [they]278-the children had been in [a besieged castle]380-a besieged castle , so [they]278-the children knew how hateful it is to be kept in when [you]381-you want to get out . Of course [they]278-the children could not buy any of the dogs . [They]278-the children did , indeed , ask the price of the very , very smallest , and it was sixty‐five pounds — but that was because it was a Japanese toy spaniel like [the Queen]382-the queen once had [her]382-the queen portrait painted with , when [she]382-the queen was only [Princess of [Wales]14-wales]383-princess of wales . But [the children]278-the children thought , if the smallest was all that money , the biggest would run into thousands — so [they]278-the children went on . And [they]278-the children did not stop at any more cat or dog or [bird shops]385-bird shops , but passed [them]386-them by , and at last [they]278-the children came to [a shop]387-a shop that seemed as though [it]387-a shop only sold creatures that did not much mind where [they]388-they were — such as goldfish and white mice , and sea‐anemones and other aquarium beasts , and lizards and toads , and hedgehogs and tortoises , and tame rabbits and guinea‐pigs . And there [they]278-the children stopped for a long time , and fed the guinea‐pigs with bits of bread through the cage‐bars , and wondered whether it would be possible to keep a sandy‐coloured double‐lop in [the basement of [the house]390-the house in [Fitzroy Street]7-fitzroy street]389-the basement of the house in fitzroy street . “ [I]134-jane do n’t suppose [old Nurse]305-old nurse would mind very much , ”[134-jane] said [Jane]134-jane . “ Rabbits are most awfully tame sometimes . [I]134-jane expect it would know [her]305-old nurse voice and follow [her]305-old nurse all about . ”[134-jane] “ [She]305-old nurse ’d tumble over it twenty times a day , ”[131-cyril] said [Cyril]131-cyril ; “ now a snake — ”[131-cyril] “ There are n’t any snakes , said [Robert]132-robert hastily , “[134-jane] and besides , [I]0-i never could cotton to snakes somehow — [I]0-i wonder why . ” “[0-i] Worms are as bad , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , “[0-i] and eels and slugs — [I]0-i think it ’s because [we]278-the children do n’t like things that have n’t got legs . ” “[137-father] [Father]137-father says snakes have got legs hidden away inside of them , ” said [Robert]132-robert . “[137-father] Yes — and [he]137-father says [we]278-the children ’ve got tails hidden away inside [us]278-the children — but it does n’t either of it come to anything really , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[137-father] [I]0-i hate things that have n’t any legs . ” “[0-i] It ’s worse when they have too many , ” said [Jane]134-jane with a shudder , “[0-i] think of centipedes ! ” [They]278-the children stood there on [the pavement]2257-the pavement , a cause of some inconvenience to [the passers‐by]2258-the passers‐by , and thus beguiled the time with conversation . [Cyril]131-cyril was leaning [his]131-cyril elbow on the top of a hutch that had seemed empty when [they]278-the children had inspected the whole edifice of hutches one by one , and [he]131-cyril was trying to reawaken the interest of a hedgehog that had curled itself into a ball earlier in the interview , when a small , soft voice just below [his]131-cyril elbow said , quietly , plainly and quite unmistakably — not in any squeak or whine that had to be translated — but in downright common English — “[137-father] Buy [me]0-i — do — please buy [me]0-i ! ” [Cyril]131-cyril started as though [he]131-cyril had been pinched , and jumped a yard away from the hutch . “[137-father] Come back — oh , come back ! ” said the voice , rather louder but still softly ; “[137-father] stoop down and pretend to be tying up [your]0-i bootlace — [I]0-i see it ’s undone , as usual . ” [Cyril]131-cyril mechanically obeyed . [He]131-cyril knelt on one knee on the dry , hot dusty pavement , peered into the darkness of [the hutch]2259-the hutch and found [himself]131-cyril face to face with — [the Psammead]136-the psammead ! [It]2259-the hutch seemed much thinner than when [he]131-cyril had last seen [it]2259-the hutch . [It]2259-the hutch was dusty and dirty , and its fur was untidy and ragged . It had hunched itself up into a miserable lump , and its long snail ’s eyes were drawn in quite tight so that they hardly showed at all . “[0-i] Listen , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , in a voice that sounded as though it would begin to cry in a minute , “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t think the creature who keeps [this shop]391-this shop will ask a very high price for [me]0-i . [I]0-i ’ve bitten [him]392-he more than once , and [I]0-i ’ve made [myself]0-i look as common as [I]0-i can . [He]392-he ’s never had a glance from [my]0-i beautiful , beautiful eyes . Tell [the others]325-the others [I]0-i ’m here — but tell [them]325-the others to look at some of those low , common beasts while [I]0-i ’m talking to [you]325-the others . The creature inside must n’t think [you]325-the others care much about [me]0-i , or [he]392-he ’ll put a price upon [me]0-i far , far beyond [your]325-the others means . [I]0-i remember in the dear old days last summer [you]325-the others never had much money . Oh — [I]0-i never thought [I]0-i should be so glad to see [you]325-the others — [I]0-i never did . ” [It]0-i sniffed , and shot out [its]0-i long snail ’s eyes expressly to drop a tear well away from [its]0-i fur . “[0-i] Tell [the others]325-the others [I]0-i ’m [here]2247-here , and then [I]0-i ’ll tell [you]325-the others exactly what to do about buying [me]0-i . ” [Cyril]131-cyril tied [his]131-cyril bootlace into a hard knot , stood up and addressed [the others]325-the others in firm tones — “[0-i] Look here , ” [he]131-cyril said , “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m not kidding — and [I]0-i appeal to [your]325-the others honour , ” an appeal which in [this family]2261-this family was never made in vain . “[0-i] Do n’t look at [that hutch]396-that hutch — look at the white rat . Now [you]325-the others are not to look at [that hutch]396-that hutch whatever [I]0-i say . ” [He]131-cyril stood in front of it to prevent mistakes . “[0-i] Now get [yourselves]325-the others ready for a great surprise . In [that hutch]396-that hutch there ’s [an old friend of ours]399-an old friend of ours — don’t look!—Yes ; it ’s [the Psammead]400-the psammead , [the good old Psammead]136-the psammead ! it wants [us]401-us to buy it . [It]402-it says [you]325-the others ’re not to look at it . Look at the white rat and count [your]325-the others money ! On [your]325-the others honour do n’t look ! ” [The others]325-the others responded nobly . [They]325-the others looked at [the white rat]2263-the white rat till [they]325-the others quite stared [him]2263-the white rat out of countenance , so that [he]2263-the white rat went and sat up on [his]2263-the white rat hind legs in a far corner and hid [his]2263-the white rat eyes with [his]2263-the white rat front paws , and pretended [he]2263-the white rat was washing [his]2263-the white rat face . [Cyril]131-cyril stooped again , busying [himself]131-cyril with the other bootlace and listened for [the Psammead]136-the psammead ’s further instructions . “[402-it] Go in , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , “[402-it] and ask the price of lots of other things . Then say , ‘ What do [you]325-the others want for that monkey that ’s lost its tail — the mangy old thing in the third hutch from the end . ’ Oh — don’t mind [my]0-i feelings — call [me]0-i [a mangy monkey]403-a mangy monkey — [I’ve]0-i tried hard enough to look like one ! [I]0-i do n’t think [he]404-he ’ll put a high price on [me]0-i — [I’ve]0-i bitten [him]404-he eleven times since [I]0-i came [here]2247-here the day before yesterday . If [he]404-he names a bigger price than [you]325-the others can afford , say [you]325-the others wish [you]325-the others had the money . ” “[325-the others] But [you]325-the others ca n’t give [us]406-us wishes . [I]0-i ’ve promised never to have another wish from [you]325-the others , ” said the bewildered [Cyril]131-cyril . “[0-i] Do n’t be [a silly little idiot]407-a silly little idiot , ” said [the Sand Fairy]146-the sand fairy in trembling but affectionate tones , “[407-a silly little idiot] but find out how much money [you]325-the others ’ve got between [you]325-the others , and do exactly what [I]0-i tell [you]325-the others . ” [Cyril]131-cyril , pointing a stiff and unmeaning finger at the white rat , so as to pretend that its charms alone employed [his]131-cyril tongue , explained matters to [the others]325-the others , while the Psammead hunched itself , and bunched itself , and did its very best to make itself look uninteresting . Then [the four children]309-the four children filed into [the shop]2266-the shop . “[0-i] How much do [you]325-the others want for that white rat ? ” asked [Cyril]131-cyril . “[325-the others] Eightpence , ” was the answer . “[325-the others] And the guinea‐pigs ? ” “[408-five bob] Eighteenpence to [five bob]408-five bob , according to the breed . ” “[408-five bob] And the lizards ? ” “[408-five bob] Ninepence each . ” “[408-five bob] And toads ? ” “[408-five bob] Fourpence . Now look here , ” said [the greasy owner of all this caged life]2267-the greasy owner of all this caged life with a sudden ferocity which made [the whole party]2268-the whole party back hurriedly on to the wainscoting of hutches with which [the shop]2266-the shop was lined . “[408-five bob] Lookee here . [I]0-i ai n’t agoin ’ to have [you]325-the others a comin ’ in here a turnin ’ [the whole place]409-the whole place outer winder , an ’ prizing every animile in the stock just for [your]325-the others larks , so do n’t think it ! If [you]325-the others ’re [a buyer]410-a buyer , be [a buyer]410-a buyer — but [I]0-i never had [a customer]412-a customer yet as wanted to buy mice , and lizards , and toads , and guineas all at once . So hout [you]325-the others goes . ” “[325-the others] Oh ! wait a minute , ” said the wretched [Cyril]131-cyril , feeling how foolishly yet well‐meaningly [he]131-cyril had carried out the Psammead ’s instructions . “[325-the others] Just tell [me]0-i one thing . What do [you]325-the others want for the mangy old monkey in the third hutch from the end ? ” [The shopman]2270-the shopman only saw in this a new insult . “[325-the others] [Mangy young monkey]413-mangy young monkey [yourself]325-the others , ” said [he]0-i ; “[325-the others] get along with [your]325-the others blooming cheek . Hout [you]325-the others goes ! ” “[325-the others] Oh ! do n’t be so cross , ” said [Jane]134-jane , losing [her]134-jane head altogether , “[325-the others] do n’t [you]325-the others see [he]414-he really does want to know that ! ” “[414-he] Ho ! does ’ [e]415-e indeed ? ” sneered [the merchant]2271-the merchant . Then [he]2271-the merchant scratched [his]2271-the merchant ear suspiciously , for [he]2271-the merchant was [a sharp business man]2272-a sharp business man , and [he]2271-the merchant knew the ring of truth when [he]2271-the merchant heard it . [His]2271-the merchant hand was bandaged , and three minutes before [he]2271-the merchant would have been glad to sell [the “[415-e] mangy old monkey ”]2273-the “ mangy old monkey ” for ten shillings . Now — “[415-e] Ho ! ’ [e]415-e does , does ’ e , ” [he]2271-the merchant said , “[415-e] then two pun ten ’s [my]0-i price . [He]414-he ’s not got [[his]414-he fellow]416-his fellow that monkey ai n’t , nor yet [his]414-he match , not this side of the equator , which [he]414-he comes from . And the only one ever seen in [London]2-london . Ought to be in [the Zoo]417-the zoo . Two pun ten , down on the nail , or hout [you]418-you goes ! ” [The children]278-the children looked at [each other]312-each other — twenty‐three shillings and fivepence was all [they]278-the children had in [the world]294-the world , and it would have been merely three and fivepence , but for the sovereign which [Father]137-father had given to [them]278-the children “[419-them] between [them]419-them ” at parting . “[420-we] [We]420-we ’ve only twenty‐three shillings and fivepence , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , rattling the money in [his]131-cyril pocket . “[420-we] Twenty‐three farthings and [somebody]421-somebody ’s own cheek , ” said [the dealer]2277-the dealer , for [he]2277-the dealer did not believe that [Cyril]131-cyril had so much money . There was a miserable pause . Then [Anthea]133-anthea remembered , and said — “[420-we] Oh ! [I]0-i wish [I]0-i had two pounds ten . ” “[0-i] So do [I]0-i , [Miss]422-miss , [I]0-i ’m sure , ” said [the man with bitter politeness]2278-the man with bitter politeness ; “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [you]422-miss ’ ad , [I]0-i ’m sure ! ” [Anthea]133-anthea ’s hand was on the counter , something seemed to slide under it . [She]133-anthea lifted it . There lay five bright half sovereigns . “[0-i] Why , [I]0-i have got it after all , ” [she]133-anthea said ; “[0-i] here ’s the money , now let ’s have [the Sammy]423-the sammy , ... the monkey [I]0-i mean . ” [The dealer]2277-the dealer looked hard at the money , but [he]2277-the dealer made haste to put it in [his]2277-the dealer pocket . “[0-i] [I]0-i only hope [you]422-miss come by it honest , ” [he]2277-the dealer said , shrugging [his]2277-the dealer shoulders . [He]2277-the dealer scratched [his]2277-the dealer ear again . “[422-miss] Well ! ” [he]2277-the dealer said , “[422-miss] [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i must let [you]422-miss have it , but it ’s worth thribble the money , so it is — ” [He]2277-the dealer slowly led the way out to [the hutch]2259-the hutch — opened the door gingerly , and made a sudden fierce grab at the Psammead , which [the Psammead]136-the psammead acknowledged in one last long lingering bite . “[0-i] Here , take the brute , ” said [the shopman]2270-the shopman , squeezing the Psammead so tight that [he]2277-the dealer nearly choked it . “[0-i] It ’s bit [me]0-i to the marrow , it have . ” [The man]2282-the man ’s eyes opened as [Anthea]133-anthea held out [her]133-anthea arms . “[0-i] Do n’t blame [me]0-i if it tears [your]422-miss face off its bones , ” [he]0-i said , and [the Psammead]136-the psammead made a leap from [his]0-i dirty horny hands , and [Anthea]133-anthea caught it in [hers]133-anthea , which were not very clean , certainly , but at any rate were soft and pink , and held it kindly and closely . “[0-i] But [you]422-miss ca n’t take it [home]357-home like that , ” [Cyril]131-cyril said , “[422-miss] [we]425-we shall have [a crowd]426-a crowd after [us]425-we , ” and indeed [two errand boys]2283-two errand boys and [a policeman]353-a policeman had already collected . “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t give [you]422-miss nothink only a paper‐bag , like what [we]425-we put the tortoises in , ” said [the man]2282-the man grudgingly . So [the whole party]2268-the whole party went into [the shop]2266-the shop , and [the shopman]2270-the shopman ’s eyes nearly came out of [his]2270-the shopman head when , having given [Anthea]133-anthea the largest paper‐bag [he]2270-the shopman could find , [he]2270-the shopman saw [her]133-anthea hold it open , and [the Psammead]400-the psammead carefully creep into it . “[425-we] Well ! ” [he]2270-the shopman said , “[425-we] if that there do n’t beat cock‐fighting ! But p’raps [you]422-miss ’ve met [the brute]427-the brute afore . ” “[427-the brute] Yes , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril affably , “[427-the brute] [he]427-the brute ’s [an old friend of ours]399-an old friend of ours . ” “[427-the brute] If [I]0-i ’d a known that , ” [the man]2282-the man rejoined , “[422-miss] [you]422-miss should n’t a had [him]427-the brute under twice the money . ’ [Owever]147-owever , ” [he]0-i added , as [the children]278-the children disappeared , “[147-owever] [I]0-i ai n’t done so bad , seeing as [I]0-i only give five bob for the beast . But then there ’s the bites to take into account ! ” [The children]278-the children trembling in agitation and excitement , carried [home]357-home [the Psammead]136-the psammead , trembling in [its]136-the psammead paper‐bag . When [they]278-the children got it [home]357-home , [Anthea]133-anthea nursed [it]136-the psammead , and stroked [it]136-the psammead , and would have cried over it , if [she]133-anthea had n’t remembered how it hated to be wet . When it recovered enough to speak , it said — “[147-owever] Get [me]0-i sand ; silver sand from [the oil and colour shop]429-the oil and colour shop . And get [me]0-i plenty . ” [They]278-the children got the sand , and [they]278-the children put it and the Psammead in [the round bath]2295-the round bath together , and it rubbed itself , and rolled itself , and shook itself and scraped itself , and scratched itself , and preened itself , till it felt clean and comfy , and then it scrabbled a hasty hole in the sand , and went to sleep in it . [The children]278-the children hid the bath under [the girls]311-the girls ’ bed , and had supper . [Old Nurse]305-old nurse had got [them]278-the children a lovely supper of bread and butter and fried onions . [She]305-old nurse was full of kind and delicate thoughts . When [Anthea]133-anthea woke the next morning , the Psammead was snuggling down between [her]133-anthea shoulder and [Jane]134-jane ’s . “[430-you] [You]430-you have saved [my]0-i life , ” it said . “[430-you] [I]0-i know [that man]431-that man would have thrown cold water on [me]0-i sooner or later , and then [I]0-i should have died . [I]0-i saw [him]431-that man wash out a guinea‐pig ’s hutch yesterday morning . [I]0-i ’m still frightfully sleepy , [I]0-i think [I]0-i ’ll go back to [sand]432-sand for another nap . Wake [the boys]313-the boys and [this doormouse of a Jane]434-this doormouse of a jane , and when [you]430-you ’ve had [your]430-you breakfasts [we]435-we ’ll have a talk . ” “[435-we] Do n’t [you]0-i want any breakfast ? ” asked [Anthea]133-anthea . “[0-i] [I]0-i daresay [I]0-i shall pick a bit presently , ” it said ; “[0-i] but sand is all [I]0-i care about — it ’s meat and drink to [me]0-i , and coals and fire and [wife]436-wife and [children]437-children . ” With these words it clambered down by the bedclothes and scrambled back into [the bath]2299-the bath , where [they]435-we heard it scratching itself out of sight . “[437-children] Well ! ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , “[437-children] anyhow [our]435-we holidays wo n’t be dull now . [We]435-we ’ve found [the Psammead]136-the psammead again . ” “[435-we] No , ” said [Jane]134-jane , beginning to put on [her]134-jane stockings . “[435-we] [We]435-we sha n’t be dull — but it ’ll be only like having a pet dog now it ca n’t give [us]435-we wishes . ” “[435-we] Oh , do n’t be so discontented , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[435-we] If it ca n’t do anything else it can tell [us]435-we about Megatheriums and things . ” LONG ago — that is to say last summer — [the children]278-the children , finding [themselves]278-the children embarrassed by some wish which [the Psammead]136-the psammead had granted [them]278-the children , and which [the servants]2301-the servants had not received in a proper spirit , had wished that [the servants]2301-the servants might not notice the gifts which [the Psammead]136-the psammead gave . And when [they]278-the children parted from [the Psammead]136-the psammead [their]278-the children last wish had been that [they]278-the children should meet it again . Therefore [they]278-the children had met it ( and it was jolly lucky for [the Psammead]136-the psammead , as [Robert]132-robert pointed out ) . Now , of course , [you]2303-you see that [the Psammead]136-the psammead ’s , being where it was , was the consequence of one of [their]435-we wishes , and therefore was a Psammead‐wish , and as such could not be noticed by [the servants]2301-the servants . And it was soon plain that in [the Psammead]136-the psammead ’s opinion [old Nurse]305-old nurse was still [a servant]2306-a servant , although [she]305-old nurse had now [a house of [her]305-old nurse own]2307-a house of her own , for [she]305-old nurse never noticed [the Psammead]136-the psammead at all . And that was as well , for [she]305-old nurse would never have consented to allow [the girls]311-the girls to keep an animal and a bath of sand under [their]311-the girls bed . When breakfast had been cleared away — it was a very nice breakfast with hot rolls to it , a luxury quite out of the common way — [Anthea]133-anthea went and dragged out the bath , and woke [the Psammead]136-the psammead . It stretched and shook itself . “[438-you] [You]438-you must have bolted [your]438-you breakfast most unwholesomely , ” it said , “[438-you] [you]438-you ca n’t have been five minutes over it . ” “[438-you] [We]439-we ’ve been nearly an hour , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[439-we] Come — [you]438-you know [you]438-you promised . ” “[438-you] Now look here , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , sitting back on the sand and shooting out its long eyes suddenly , “[438-you] [we]439-we ’d better begin as [we]439-we mean to go on . It wo n’t do to have any misunderstanding , so [I]0-i tell [you]438-you plainly that — ” “[0-i] Oh , please , ” [Anthea]133-anthea pleaded , “[0-i] do wait till [we]439-we get to [the others]325-the others . [They]325-the others ’ll think it most awfully sneakish of [me]0-i to talk to [you]438-you without [them]325-the others ; do come down , there ’s [a dear]441-a dear . ” [She]133-anthea knelt before the sand‐bath and held out [her]133-anthea arms . [The Psammead]136-the psammead must have remembered how glad it had been to jump into those same little arms , only the day before , for it gave a little grudging grunt , and jumped once more . [Anthea]133-anthea wrapped [it]136-the psammead in [her]133-anthea pinafore and carried it [downstairs]2309-downstairs . [It]136-the psammead was welcomed in a thrilling silence . At last [Anthea]133-anthea said , “[441-a dear] Now then ! ” “[441-a dear] What place is this ? ” asked [the Psammead]136-the psammead , shooting [its]136-the psammead eyes out and turning them slowly round . “[441-a dear] [It]442-it ’s [a sitting‐room]443-a sitting‐room , of course , ” said [Robert]132-robert . “[441-a dear] Then [I]0-i do n’t like it , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead . “[0-i] Never mind , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea kindly ; “[441-a dear] [we]444-we ’ll take [you]0-i anywhere [you]0-i like if [you]0-i want [us]444-we to . What was it [you]0-i were going to say [upstairs]445-upstairs when [I]0-i said [the others]325-the others would n’t like it if [I]0-i stayed talking to [you]0-i without [them]325-the others ? ” [It]0-i looked keenly at [her]133-anthea , and [she]133-anthea blushed . “[0-i] Do n’t be silly , ” it said sharply . “[0-i] Of course , it ’s quite natural that [you]0-i should like [[your]0-i brothers]447-your brothers and [sisters]448-sisters to know exactly how good and unselfish [you]0-i were . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [you]0-i would n’t , ” said [Jane]134-jane . “[0-i] [Anthea]133-anthea was quite right . What was it [you]0-i were going to say when [she]133-anthea stopped [you]0-i ? ” “[133-anthea] [I]0-i ’ll tell [you]0-i , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , “[0-i] since [you]0-i ’re so anxious to know . [I]0-i was going to say this . [You]0-i ’ve saved [my]0-i life — and [I]0-i ’m not ungrateful — but it does n’t change [your]0-i nature or mine . [You]0-i ’re still very ignorant , and rather silly , and [I]0-i am worth a thousand of [you]0-i any day of the week . ” “[0-i] Of course [you]0-i are ! ” [Anthea]133-anthea was beginning but [it]0-i interrupted [her]133-anthea . “[0-i] It ’s very rude to interrupt , ” [it]0-i said ; “[0-i] what [I]0-i mean is that [I]0-i ’m not going to stand any nonsense , and if [you]0-i think what [you]0-i ’ve done is to give [you]0-i the right to pet [me]0-i or make [me]0-i demean [myself]0-i by playing with [you]0-i , [you]0-i ’ll find out that what [you]0-i think does n’t matter a single penny . See ? It ’s what [I]0-i think that matters . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i know , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , “[0-i] it always was , if [you]0-i remember . ” “[0-i] Well , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , “[0-i] then that ’s settled . [We]449-we ’re to be treated as [we]449-we deserve . [I]0-i with respect , and all of [you]0-i with — but [I]0-i do n’t wish to be offensive . Do [you]0-i want [me]0-i to tell [you]0-i how [I]0-i got into [that horrible den [you]0-i bought [me]0-i out of]450-that horrible den you bought me out of ? Oh , [I]0-i ’m not ungrateful ! [I]0-i have n’t forgotten it and [I]0-i sha n’t forget it . ” “[0-i] Do tell [us]449-we , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[0-i] [I]0-i know [you]0-i ’re awfully clever , but even with all [your]0-i cleverness , [I]0-i do n’t believe [you]0-i can possibly know how — how respectfully [we]449-we do respect [you]0-i . Do n’t [we]449-we ? ” [The others]325-the others all said yes — and fidgetted in [their]325-the others chairs . [Robert]132-robert spoke the wishes of all when [he]132-robert said — “[449-we] [I]0-i do wish [you]0-i ’d go on . ” So it sat up on the green‐covered table and went on . “[0-i] When [you]0-i ’d gone away , ” it said , “[0-i] [I]0-i went to sand for a bit , and slept . [I]0-i was tired out with all [your]0-i silly wishes , and [I]0-i felt as though [I]0-i had n’t really been to sand for a year . ” “[0-i] To sand ? ” [Jane]134-jane repeated . “[0-i] Where [I]0-i sleep . [You]0-i go to bed . [I]0-i go to sand . ” [Jane]134-jane yawned ; the mention of bed made [her]134-jane feel sleepy . “[0-i] All right , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , in offended tones . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m sure [I]0-i do n’t want to tell [you]0-i a long tale . [A man]451-a man caught [me]0-i , and [I]0-i bit [him]451-a man . And [he]451-a man put [me]0-i in a bag with a dead hare and a dead rabbit . And [he]451-a man took [me]0-i to [[his]451-a man house]452-his house and put [me]0-i out of the bag into a basket with holes that [I]0-i could see through . And [I]0-i bit [him]451-a man again . And then [he]451-a man brought [me]0-i to [this city]453-this city , which [I]0-i am told is called [the Modern Babylon]454-the modern babylon — though it ’s not a bit like [the old Babylon]455-the old babylon — and [he]451-a man sold [me]0-i to [the man [you]457-you bought [me]0-i of]456-the man you bought me of , and then [I]0-i bit [them]458-they both . Now , what ’s [your]457-you news ? ” “[457-you] There ’s not quite so much biting in [our]459-our story , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril regretfully ; “[457-you] in fact , there is n’t any . [Father]137-father ’s gone to [Manchuria]4-manchuria , and [Mother]138-mother and [The Lamb]145-the lamb have gone to [Madeira]5-madeira because [Mother]138-mother was ill , and do n’t [I]0-i just wish that [they]458-they were both safe [home]357-home again . ” Merely from habit , [the Sand‐fairy]2311-the sand‐fairy began to blow itself out , but it stopped short suddenly . “[0-i] [I]0-i forgot , ” it said ; “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t give [you]457-you any more wishes . ” “[0-i] No — but look here , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , “[459-our] could n’t [we]459-our call in [old Nurse]305-old nurse and get [her]305-old nurse to say [she]305-old nurse wishes [they]458-they were safe [home]357-home . [I]0-i ’m sure [she]305-old nurse does . ” “[305-old nurse] No go , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead . “[305-old nurse] It ’s just the same as [your]463-you wishing [yourself]463-you if [you]463-you get some one else to wish for [you]463-you . It wo n’t act . ” “[464-the man in the shop] But it did yesterday — with [the man in [the shop]2266-the shop]464-the man in the shop , ” said [Robert]132-robert . “[464-the man in the shop] Ah yes , ” said [the creature]2312-the creature , “[464-the man in the shop] but [you]457-you did n’t ask [him]464-the man in the shop to wish , and [you]457-you did n’t know what would happen if [he]464-the man in the shop did . That ca n’t be done again . It ’s played out . ” “[457-you] Then [you]457-you ca n’t help [us]466-us at all , ” said [Jane]134-jane ; “[457-you] oh — [I]0-i did think [you]457-you could do something ! [I]0-i ’ve been thinking about it ever since [we]466-us saved [your]457-you life yesterday . [I]0-i thought [you]457-you ’d be certain to be able to fetch back [Father]137-father , even if [you]457-you could n’t manage [Mother]138-mother . ” And [Jane]134-jane began to cry . “[138-mother] Now do n’t , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead hastily ; “[457-you] [you]457-you know how it always upsets [me]0-i if [you]457-you cry . [I]0-i ca n’t feel safe a moment . Look here ; [you]457-you must have some new kind of charm . ” “[457-you] That ’s easier said than done . ” “[457-you] Not a bit of it , ” said [the creature]2312-the creature ; “[457-you] there ’s one of the strongest charms in [the world]294-the world not a stone ’s throw from where [you]457-you bought [me]0-i yesterday . [The man that [I]0-i bit so]468-the man that i bit so — the first one , [I]0-i mean — went into [a shop]387-a shop to ask how much something cost — [I]0-i think [he]468-the man that i bit so said it was a concertina — and while [he]468-the man that i bit so was telling [the man in [the shop]2266-the shop]464-the man in the shop how much too much [he]468-the man that i bit so wanted for it , [I]0-i saw the charm in a sort of tray , with a lot of other things . If [you]457-you can only buy that , [you]457-you will be able to have [your]457-you heart ’s desire . ” [The children]278-the children looked at [each other]312-each other and then at the Psammead . Then [Cyril]131-cyril coughed awkwardly and took sudden courage to say what [everyone]319-everyone was thinking . “[0-i] [I]0-i do hope [you]472-you wo n’t be waxy , ” [he]0-i said ; “[472-you] but it ’s like this : when [you]457-you used to give [us]473-we [our]473-we wishes [they]474-they almost always got [us]473-we into some row or other , and [we]473-we used to think [you]457-you would n’t have been pleased if [they]474-they had n’t . Now , about this charm — [we]473-we have n’t got over and above too much tin , and if [we]473-we blue it all on this charm and it turns out to be not up to much — well — [you]472-you see what [I]0-i ’m driving at , do n’t [you]472-you ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i see that [you]472-you do n’t see more than the length of [your]472-you nose , and that ’s not far , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead crossly . “[472-you] Look here , [I]0-i had to give [you]472-you the wishes , and of course they turned out badly , in a sort of way , because [you]472-you had n’t the sense to wish for what was good for [you]472-you . But this charm ’s quite different . [I]0-i have n’t got to do this for [you]472-you , it ’s just [my]0-i own generous kindness that makes [me]0-i tell [you]472-you about it . So it ’s bound to be all right . See ? ” “[472-you] Do n’t be cross , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , “[472-you] please , please do n’t . [You]472-you see , it ’s all [we]473-we ’ve got ; [we]473-we sha n’t have any more pocket‐money till [Daddy]148-daddy comes [home]357-home — unless [he]148-daddy sends [us]473-we some in a letter . But [we]473-we do trust [you]472-you . And [I]0-i say , all of [you]472-you , ” [she]133-anthea went on , “[0-i] do n’t [you]472-you think it ’s worth spending all the money , if there ’s even the chanciest chance of getting [Father]137-father and [Mother]138-mother back safe now ? Just think of it ! Oh , do let ’s ! ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t care what [you]472-you do , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead ; “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ll go back to sand again till [you]472-you ’ve made up [your]472-you minds . ” “[472-you] No , do n’t ! ” said [everybody]2317-everybody ; and [Jane]134-jane added , “[472-you] [We]473-we are quite mind‐made‐up — don’t [you]472-you see [we]473-we are ? [Let]476-let [’s]476-let get [our]476-let hats . Will [you]472-you come with [us]476-let ? ” “[472-you] Of course , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead ; “[472-you] how else would [you]472-you find [the shop]2266-the shop ? ” So [everybody]2317-everybody got [its]2317-everybody hat . [The Psammead]136-the psammead was put into a flat bass‐bag that had come from [Farringdon Market]15-farringdon market with two pounds of filleted plaice in it . Now it contained about three pounds and a quarter of solid Psammead , and [the children]278-the children took it in turns to carry it . “[472-you] It ’s not half the weight of [The Lamb]145-the lamb , ” [Robert]132-robert said , and [the girls]311-the girls sighed . [The Psammead]136-the psammead poked a wary eye out of the top of the basket every now and then , and told [the children]278-the children which turnings to take . “[472-you] How on earth do [you]472-you know ? ” asked [Robert]132-robert . “[472-you] [I]0-i ca n’t think how [you]472-you do it . ” And [the Psammead]136-the psammead said sharply , “[0-i] No — [I]0-i do n’t suppose [you]472-you can . ” At last [they]278-the children came to [the shop]2266-the shop . [It]2266-the shop had all sorts and kinds of things in the window — concertinas , and silk handkerchiefs , china vases and tea‐cups , blue Japanese jars , pipes , swords , pistols , lace collars , silver spoons tied up in half‐dozens , and wedding‐rings in a red lacquered basin . There were [officers]2323-officers ’ epaulets and [doctors]2324-doctors ’ lancets . There were tea‐caddies inlaid with red turtle‐shell and brass curly‐wurlies , plates of different kinds of money , and stacks of different kinds of plates . There was a beautiful picture of [a little girl]323-a little girl washing a dog , which [Jane]134-jane liked very much . And in the middle of the window there was a dirty silver tray full of mother‐of‐pearl card counters , old seals , paste buckles , snuff‐boxes , and all sorts of little dingy odds and ends . [The Psammead]136-the psammead put its head quite out of the fish‐basket to look in the window , when [Cyril]131-cyril said — “[0-i] There ’s a tray there with rubbish in it . ” And then its long snail ’s eyes saw something that made them stretch out so much that they were as long and thin as new slate‐pencils . Its fur bristled thickly , and its voice was quite hoarse with excitement as it whispered — “[0-i] That ’s it ! That ’s it ! There , under that blue and yellow buckle , [you]472-you can see a bit sticking out . It ’s red . Do [you]472-you see ? ” “[472-you] Is it that thing something like a horse‐shoe ? ” asked [Cyril]131-cyril . “[472-you] And red , like the common sealing‐wax [you]472-you do up parcels with ? ” “[472-you] Yes , that ’s it , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead . “[472-you] Now , [you]472-you do just as [you]472-you did before . Ask the price of other things . That blue buckle would do . Then [the man]2282-the man will get the tray out of the window . [I]0-i think [you]472-you ’d better be the one , ” it said to [Anthea]133-anthea . “[472-you] [We]479-they ’ll wait out here . ” So [the others]325-the others flattened [their]325-the others noses against the shop window , and presently a large , dirty , short‐fingered hand with a very big diamond ring came stretching through the green half‐ curtains at the back of the shop window and took away the tray . [They]325-the others could not see what was happening in the interview between [Anthea]133-anthea and the Diamond Ring , and it seemed to [them]325-the others that [she]133-anthea had had time — if [she]133-anthea had had money — to buy everything in [the shop]2266-the shop before the moment came when [she]133-anthea stood before [them]325-the others , [her]133-anthea face wreathed in grins , as [Cyril]131-cyril said later , and in [her]133-anthea hand the charm . It was something like this — and it was made of a red , smooth , softly shiny stone . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ve got it , ” [Anthea]133-anthea whispered , just opening [her]133-anthea hand to give [the others]325-the others a glimpse of it . “[0-i] Do let ’s get [home]357-home . [We]479-they ca n’t stand here like stuck‐pigs looking at it in [the street]481-the street . ” So [home]357-home [they]479-they went . [The parlour in [Fitzroy Street]7-fitzroy street]2330-the parlour in fitzroy street was a very flat background to magic happenings . Down in [the country among the flowers and green fields]2331-the country among the flowers and green fields anything had seemed — and indeed had been — possible . But it was hard to believe that anything really wonderful could happen so near [the Tottenham Court Road]2332-the tottenham court road . But [the Psammead]136-the psammead was there — and it in itself was wonderful . And it could talk — and it had shown [them]325-the others where a charm could be bought that would make [the owner of it]2333-the owner of it perfectly happy . So [the four children]309-the four children hurried [home]357-home , taking very long steps , with [their]309-the four children chins stuck out , and [their]309-the four children mouths shut very tight indeed . [They]479-they went so fast that [the Psammead]136-the psammead was quite shaken about in its fish‐bag , but it did not say anything — perhaps for fear of attracting public notice . [They]479-they got [home]357-home at last , very hot indeed , and set the Psammead on the green tablecloth . “[479-they] Now then ! ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . But [the Psammead]136-the psammead had to have a plate of sand fetched for it , for it was quite faint . When it had refreshed itself a little it said — “[479-they] Now then ! Let [me]0-i see the charm , ” and [Anthea]133-anthea laid it on the green table‐cover . [The Psammead]136-the psammead shot out [his]0-i long eyes to look at it , then it turned [them]325-the others reproachfully on [Anthea]133-anthea and said — “[0-i] But there ’s only half of it here ! ” This was indeed a blow . “[0-i] It was all there was , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , with timid firmness . [She]133-anthea knew it was not [her]133-anthea fault . “[0-i] there should be another piece , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , “[0-i] and a sort of pin to fasten the two together . ” “[0-i] Is n’t half any good?”—“Won’t it work without the other bit?”—“It[0-i] cost seven‐and‐six . ”—“Oh , bother , bother , bother!”—“Don’t[482-silly little idiots] be [silly little idiots]482-silly little idiots ! ” said [everyone]319-everyone and [the Psammead]136-the psammead altogether . Then there was a wretched silence . [Cyril]131-cyril broke it — “[482-silly little idiots] What shall [we]483-we do ? ” “[482-silly little idiots] Go back to [the shop]2266-the shop and see if [they]485-they have n’t got the other half , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ll go to sand till [you]486-you come back . Cheer up ! Even the bit [you]486-you ’ve got is some good , but it ’ll be no end of a bother if [you]486-you ca n’t find the other . ” So [Cyril]131-cyril went to [the shop]2266-the shop . And the Psammead to sand . And [the other three]2339-the other three went to dinner , which was now ready . And [old Nurse]142-old nurse was very cross that [Cyril]131-cyril was not ready too . [The three]2340-the three were watching at the windows when [Cyril]131-cyril returned , and even before [he]131-cyril was near enough for [them]2340-the three to see [his]131-cyril face there was something about the slouch of [his]131-cyril shoulders and set of [his]131-cyril knickerbockers and the way [he]131-cyril dragged [his]131-cyril boots along that showed but too plainly that [his]131-cyril errand had been vain . “[2282-the man] Well ? ” [they]2340-the three all said , hoping against hope on the front‐door step . “[2282-the man] No go , ” [Cyril]131-cyril answered ; “[2282-the man] [the man]2282-the man said the thing was perfect . [He]2282-the man said it was [a Roman lady]488-a roman lady ’s locket , and [people]280-people should n’t buy curios if [they]280-people did n’t know anything about arky — something or other , and that [he]2282-the man never went back on a bargain , because it was n’t business , and [he]2282-the man expected [[his]2282-the man customers]490-his customers to act the same . [He]2282-the man was simply nasty — that ’s what [he]2282-the man was , and [I]0-i want [my]0-i dinner . ” It was plain that [Cyril]131-cyril was not pleased . The unlikeliness of anything really interesting happening in [that parlour]2341-that parlour lay like a weight of lead on [everyone]319-everyone ’s spirits . [Cyril]131-cyril had [his]131-cyril dinner , and just as [he]131-cyril was swallowing the last mouthful of apple‐pudding there was a scratch at the door . [Anthea]133-anthea opened it and in walked [the Psammead]136-the psammead . “[2282-the man] Well , ” it said , when it had heard the news , “[2282-the man] things might be worse . Only [you]491-you wo n’t be surprised if [you]491-you have a few adventures before [you]491-you get the other half . [You]491-you want to get it , of course . ” “[491-you] Rather , ” was [the general]2343-the general reply . “[491-you] And [we]492-we do n’t mind adventures . ” “[492-we] No , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , “[492-we] [I]0-i seem to remember that about [you]491-you . Well , sit down and listen with all [your]491-you ears . [Eight]149-eight , are there ? Right — [I]0-i am glad [you]491-you know arithmetic . Now pay attention , because [I]0-i do n’t intend to tell [you]491-you everything twice over . ” As [the children]278-the children settled [themselves]278-the children on the floor — it was far more comfortable than the chairs , as well as more polite to the Psammead , who was stroking its whiskers on the hearth‐rug — a sudden cold pain caught at [Anthea]133-anthea ’s heart . [Father]137-father — [Mother]297-mother — [the darling Lamb]2346-the darling lamb — all far away . Then a warm , comfortable feeling flowed through [her]133-anthea . [The Psammead]136-the psammead was here , and at least half a charm , and there were to be adventures . ( If [you]491-you do n’t know what a cold pain is , [I]0-i am glad for [your]491-you sakes , and [I]0-i hope [you]491-you never may . ) “[0-i] Now , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead cheerily , “[0-i] [you]491-you are not particularly nice , nor particularly clever , and [you]491-you ’re not at all good‐looking . Still , [you]491-you ’ve saved [my]0-i life — oh , when [I]0-i think of [that man]431-that man and [his]431-that man pail of water!—so [I]0-i ’ll tell [you]491-you all [I]0-i know . At least , of course [I]0-i ca n’t do that , because [I]0-i know far too much . But [I]0-i ’ll tell [you]491-you all [I]0-i know about this red thing . ” “[0-i] Do ! Do ! Do ! Do ! ” said [every one]2347-every one . “[0-i] Well , then , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead . “[0-i] This thing is half of an amulet that can do all sorts of things ; it can make the corn grow , and the waters flow , and the trees bear fruit , and [the little new beautiful babies]494-the little new beautiful babies come . ( Not that [babies]495-babies are beautiful , of course , ” it broke off to say , “[496-their mothers] but [[their]495-babies mothers]496-their mothers think [they]495-babies are — and as long as [you]491-you think a thing ’s true it is true as far as [you]491-you ’re concerned . ” ) [Robert]132-robert yawned . [The Psammead]136-the psammead went on . “[280-people] The complete Amulet can keep off all the things that make [people]280-people unhappy — jealousy , bad temper , pride , disagreeableness , greediness , selfishness , laziness . [Evil spirits]498-evil spirits , [people]280-people called [them]498-evil spirits when the Amulet was made . Do n’t [you]491-you think it would be nice to have it ? ” “[491-you] Very , ” said [the children]278-the children , quite without enthusiasm . “[491-you] And it can give [you]491-you strength and courage . ” “[491-you] That ’s better , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[491-you] And virtue . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose it ’s nice to have that , ” said [Jane]134-jane , but not with much interest . “[0-i] And it can give [you]491-you [your]491-you heart ’s desire . ” “[0-i] Now [you]500-you ’re talking , ” said [Robert]132-robert . “[500-you] Of course [I]0-i am , ” retorted [the Psammead]136-the psammead tartly , “[0-i] so there ’s no need for [you]491-you to . ” “[491-you] Heart ’s desire ’s good enough for [me]0-i , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[491-you] Yes , but , ” [Anthea]133-anthea ventured , “[491-you] all that ’s what the whole charm can do . There ’s something that the half [we]501-we ’ve got can win off [its]502-its own bat — isn’t there ? ” [She]133-anthea appealed to [the Psammead]136-the psammead . [It]136-the psammead nodded . “[502-its] Yes , ” it said ; “[502-its] the half has the power to take [you]491-you anywhere [you]491-you like to look for the other half . ” This seemed a brilliant prospect till [Robert]132-robert asked — “[502-its] Does it know where to look ? ” [The Psammead]136-the psammead shook [its]136-the psammead head and answered , “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t think it ’s likely . ” “[0-i] Do [you]0-i ? ” “[0-i] No . ” “[0-i] Then , ” said [Robert]132-robert , “[0-i] [we]501-we might as well look for a needle in a bottle of hay . Yes — it is bottle , and not bundle , [Father]137-father said so . ” “[137-father] Not at all , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead briskly ; “[491-you] [you]491-you think [you]491-you know everything , but [you]491-you are quite mistaken . The first thing is to get the thing to talk . ” “[137-father] Can it ? ” [Jane]134-jane questioned . [Jane]134-jane ’s question did not mean that [she]134-jane thought it could n’t , for in spite of the parlour furniture the feeling of magic was growing deeper and thicker , and seemed to fill [the room]2349-the room like a dream of a scented fog . “[137-father] Of course it can . [I]0-i suppose [you]491-you can read . ” “[491-you] Oh yes ! ” [Every one]2347-every one was rather hurt at the question . “[491-you] Well , then — all [you]491-you ’ve got to do is to read the name that ’s written on the part of the charm that [you]491-you ’ve got . And as soon as [you]491-you say the name out loud the thing will have power to do — well , several things . ” There was a silence . The red charm was passed from hand to hand . “[491-you] There ’s no name on it , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril at last . “[491-you] Nonsense , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead ; “[491-you] what ’s that ? ” “[491-you] Oh , that ! ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , “[491-you] it ’s not reading . It looks like pictures of chickens and snakes and things . ” This was what was on the charm — “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ve no patience with [you]491-you , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead ; “[0-i] if [you]491-you ca n’t read [you]491-you must find [some one who can]503-some one who can . [A priest]504-a priest now ? ” “[504-a priest] [We]505-we do n’t know [any priests]506-any priests , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea ; “[505-we] [we]505-we know [a clergyman]507-a clergyman — [he]507-a clergyman ’s called [a priest in the prayer‐book]508-a priest in the prayer‐book , [you]491-you know — but [he]507-a clergyman only knows Greek and Latin and Hebrew , and this is n’t any of those — [I]0-i know . ” [The Psammead]136-the psammead stamped a furry foot angrily . “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i ’d never seen [you]491-you , ” it said ; “[0-i] [you]491-you are n’t any more good than so many stone images . Not so much , if [I]0-i ’m to tell the truth . Is there [no wise man in [[your]491-you Babylon]510-your babylon who can pronounce the names of [the Great Ones]511-the great ones]509-no wise man in your babylon who can pronounce the names of the great ones ? ” “[509-no wise man in your babylon who can pronounce the names of the great ones] There ’s [a poor learned gentleman]512-a poor learned gentleman [upstairs]445-upstairs , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , “[509-no wise man in your babylon who can pronounce the names of the great ones] [we]505-we might try [him]512-a poor learned gentleman . [He]512-a poor learned gentleman has a lot of stone images in [[his]512-a poor learned gentleman room]514-his room , and iron‐looking ones too — [we]505-we peeped in once when [he]512-a poor learned gentleman was out . [Old Nurse]305-old nurse says [he]512-a poor learned gentleman does n’t eat enough to keep a canary alive . [He]512-a poor learned gentleman spends it all on stones and things . ” “[512-a poor learned gentleman] Try [him]512-a poor learned gentleman , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , “[512-a poor learned gentleman] only be careful . If [he]512-a poor learned gentleman knows a greater name than this and uses it against [you]491-you , [your]491-you charm will be of no use . Bind [him]512-a poor learned gentleman first with the chains of honour and upright dealing . And then ask [his]512-a poor learned gentleman aid — oh , yes , [you]491-you ’d better all go ; [you]491-you can put [me]0-i to sand as [you]491-you go [upstairs]445-upstairs . [I]0-i must have a few minutes ’ peace and quietness . ” So [the four children]309-the four children hastily washed [their]309-the four children hands and brushed [their]309-the four children hair — this was [Anthea]133-anthea ’s idea — and went up to knock at the door of [the “[0-i] poor learned gentleman]2352-the “ poor learned gentleman , ” and to “[0-i] bind [him]512-a poor learned gentleman with the chains of honour and upright dealing . ” [THE learned gentleman]2353-the learned gentleman had let [his]2353-the learned gentleman dinner get quite cold . It was mutton chop , and as it lay on the plate it looked like a brown island in the middle of [a frozen pond]2354-a frozen pond , because the grease of the gravy had become cold , and consequently white . It looked very nasty , and it was the first thing [the children]278-the children saw when , after knocking three times and receiving no reply , [one of [them]278-the children]2356-one of them ventured to turn the handle and softly to open the door . The chop was on the end of a long table that ran down one side of [the room]2349-the room . The table had images on it and queer‐shaped stones , and books . And there were glass cases fixed against the wall behind , with little strange things in them . The cases were rather like the ones [you]2358-you see in [[jewellers]2359-jewellers ’ shops]2360-jewellers ’ shops . [The “[0-i] poor learned gentleman ”]2361-the “ poor learned gentleman ” was sitting at a table in the window , looking at something very small which [he]2361-the “ poor learned gentleman ” held in a pair of fine pincers . [He]2361-the “ poor learned gentleman ” had a round spy‐glass sort of thing in one eye — which reminded [the children]278-the children of [watchmakers]2363-watchmakers , and also of the long snail ’s eyes of the Psammead . [The gentleman]2364-the gentleman was very long and thin , and [his]2361-the “ poor learned gentleman ” long , thin boots stuck out under the other side of [his]2361-the “ poor learned gentleman ” table . [He]2361-the “ poor learned gentleman ” did not hear the door open , and [the children]278-the children stood hesitating . At last [Robert]132-robert gave the door a push , and [they]278-the children all started back , for in the middle of the wall that the door had hidden was a mummy‐case — very , very , very big — painted in red and yellow and green and black , and the face of it seemed to look at [them]278-the children quite angrily . [You]2358-you know what a mummy‐case is like , of course ? If [you]2358-you do n’t [you]2358-you had better go to [the British Museum]306-the british museum at once and find out . Anyway , it is not at all the sort of thing that [you]2358-you expect to meet in a top‐floor front in [Bloomsbury]16-bloomsbury , looking as though it would like to know what business [you]2358-you had there . So [everyone]319-everyone said , “[0-i] Oh ! ” rather loud , and [their]319-everyone boots clattered as [they]319-everyone stumbled back . [The learned gentleman]2353-the learned gentleman took the glass out of [his]2353-the learned gentleman eye and said — “[0-i] [I]0-i beg [your]517-you pardon , ” in a very soft , quiet pleasant voice — the voice of [a gentleman who has been to [Oxford]17-oxford]2369-a gentleman who has been to oxford . “[0-i] It ’s [us]518-we that beg [yours]517-you , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril politely . “[518-we] [We]518-we are sorry to disturb [you]517-you . ” “[518-we] Come in , ” said [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman , rising — with the most distinguished courtesy , [Anthea]133-anthea told [herself]133-anthea . “[0-i] [I]0-i am delighted to see [you]517-you . Wo n’t [you]517-you sit down ? No , not there ; allow [me]0-i to move that papyrus . ” [He]2364-the gentleman cleared a chair , and stood smiling and looking kindly through [his]2364-the gentleman large , round spectacles . “[0-i] [He]0-i treats [us]518-we like grown‐ups , ” whispered [Robert]132-robert , “[0-i] and [he]0-i does n’t seem to know how many of [us]518-we there are . ” “[0-i] Hush , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , “[0-i] it is n’t manners to whisper . [You]517-you say , [Cyril]131-cyril — go ahead . ” “[517-you] [We]518-we ’re very sorry to disturb [you]517-you , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril politely , “[518-we] but [we]518-we did knock three times , and [you]517-you did n’t say ‘ Come in , ’ or ‘ Run away now , ’ or that [you]517-you could n’t be bothered just now , or to come when [you]517-you were n’t so busy , or any of the things [people]280-people do say when [you]517-you knock at doors , so [we]518-we opened it . [We]518-we knew [you]517-you were in because [we]518-we heard [you]517-you sneeze while [we]518-we were waiting . ” “[517-you] Not at all , ” said [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman ; “[517-you] do sit down . ” “[520-he] [He]520-he has found out there are [four of [us]518-we]521-four of us , ” said [Robert]132-robert , as [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman cleared three more chairs . [He]2364-the gentleman put the things off them carefully on the floor . The first chair had things like bricks that tiny , tiny birds ’ feet have walked over when the bricks were soft , only the marks were in regular lines . The second chair had round things on it like very large , fat , long , pale beads . And the last chair had a pile of dusty papers on it . [The children]278-the children sat down . “[520-he] [We]518-we know [you]517-you are very , very learned , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , “[517-you] and [we]518-we have got a charm , and [we]518-we want [you]517-you to read the name on it , because it is n’t in Latin or Greek , or Hebrew , or any of the languages [we]518-we know — ” “[518-we] A thorough knowledge of even those languages is a very fair foundation on which to build an education , ” said [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman politely . “[518-we] Oh ! ” said [Cyril]131-cyril blushing , “[518-we] but [we]518-we only know [them]522-them to look at , except Latin — and [I]0-i ’m only in [Cæsar]236-cæsar with that . ” [The gentleman]2364-the gentleman took off [his]2364-the gentleman spectacles and laughed . [His]2364-the gentleman laugh sounded rusty , [Cyril]131-cyril thought , as though it was n’t often used . “[0-i] Of course ! ” [he]0-i said . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m sure [I]0-i beg [your]517-you pardon . [I]0-i think [I]0-i must have been in a dream . [You]517-you are [the children]278-the children who live [downstairs]2309-downstairs , are [you]517-you not ? Yes . [I]0-i have seen [you]517-you as [I]0-i have passed in and out . And [you]517-you have found something that [you]517-you think to be an antiquity , and [you]517-you ’ve brought it to show [me]0-i ? That was very kind . [I]0-i should like to inspect it . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m afraid [we]525-we did n’t think about [your]517-you liking to inspect it , ” said [the truthful Anthea]133-anthea . “[525-we] It was just for [us]525-we because [we]525-we wanted to know the name on it — ” “[525-we] Oh , yes — and , [I]0-i say , ” [Robert]132-robert interjected , “[0-i] [you]517-you wo n’t think it rude of [us]525-we if [we]525-we ask [you]517-you first , before [we]525-we show it , to be bound in the what‐do‐you‐call‐it of — ” “[0-i] In the bonds of honour and upright dealing , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m afraid [I]0-i do n’t quite follow [you]517-you , ” said [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman , with gentle nervousness . “[0-i] Well , it ’s this way , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[525-we] [We]525-we ’ve got part of a charm . And [the Sammy]150-the sammy — [I]0-i mean , something told [us]525-we it would work , though it ’s only half a one ; but it wo n’t work unless [we]525-we can say the name that ’s on it . But , of course , if [you]517-you ’ve got another name that can lick [ours]525-we , [our]525-we charm will be no go ; so [we]525-we want [you]517-you to give [us]525-we [your]517-you word of honour as [a gentleman]526-a gentleman — though [I]0-i ’m sure , now [I]0-i ’ve seen [you]517-you , that it ’s not necessary ; but still [I]0-i ’ve promised to ask [you]517-you , so [we]525-we must . Will [you]517-you please give [us]525-we [your]517-you honourable word not to say any name stronger than the name on [our]525-we charm ? ” [The gentleman]2364-the gentleman had put on [his]2364-the gentleman spectacles again and was looking at [Cyril]131-cyril through them . [He]2364-the gentleman now said : “[517-you] Bless [me]0-i ! ” more than once , adding , “[517-you] Who told [you]517-you all this ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t tell [you]517-you , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m very sorry , but [I]0-i ca n’t . ” Some faint memory of a far‐off childhood must have come to [the learned gentleman]2353-the learned gentleman just then , for [he]2364-the gentleman smiled . “[0-i] [I]0-i see , ” [he]2364-the gentleman said . “[0-i] It is some sort of game that [you]517-you are engaged in ? Of course ! Yes ! Well , [I]0-i will certainly promise . Yet [I]0-i wonder how [you]517-you heard of the names of power ? ” “[517-you] [We]525-we ca n’t tell [you]517-you that either , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril ; and [Anthea]133-anthea said , “[525-we] Here is [our]525-we charm , ” and held it out . With politeness , but without interest , [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman took it . But after the first glance all [his]2364-the gentleman body suddenly stiffened , as a pointer ’s does when [he]2364-the gentleman sees a partridge . “[525-we] Excuse [me]0-i , ” [he]2364-the gentleman said in quite a changed voice , and carried the charm to the window . [He]2364-the gentleman looked at it ; [he]2364-the gentleman turned it over . [He]2364-the gentleman fixed [his]2364-the gentleman spy‐glass in [his]2364-the gentleman eye and looked again .
