[No one]344-no one said anything . Only [Robert]132-robert made a shuffling noise with [his]132-robert feet till [Anthea]133-anthea nudged [him]132-robert to shut up . At last [the learned gentleman]2353-the learned gentleman drew a long breath . “[525-we] Where did [you]517-you find this ? ” [he]2353-the learned gentleman asked . “[517-you] [We]525-we did n’t find it . [We]525-we bought it at [a shop]387-a shop . [Jacob Absalom]151-jacob absalom the name is — [not far from [Charing Cross]19-charing cross]528-not far from charing cross , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[525-we] [We]525-we gave seven‐and‐sixpence for it , ” added [Jane]134-jane . “[525-we] It is not for sale , [I]0-i suppose ? [You]517-you do not wish to part with it ? [I]0-i ought to tell [you]517-you that it is extremely valuable — extraordinarily valuable , [I]0-i may say . ” “[0-i] Yes , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , “[0-i] [we]525-we know that , so of course [we]525-we want to keep it . ” “[525-we] Keep it carefully , then , ” said [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman impressively ; “[525-we] and if ever [you]517-you should wish to part with it , may [I]0-i ask [you]517-you to give [me]0-i the refusal of it ? ” “[0-i] The refusal ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i mean , do not sell it to [anyone else]529-anyone else until [you]517-you have given [me]0-i the opportunity of buying it . ” “[517-you] All right , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , “[525-we] [we]525-we wo n’t . But [we]525-we do n’t want to sell it . [We]525-we want to make it do things . ” “[525-we] [I]0-i suppose [you]517-you can play at that as well as at anything else , ” said [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman ; “[517-you] but [I]0-i ’m afraid the days of magic are over . ” “[0-i] [They]530-they are n’t really , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea earnestly . “[530-they] [You]517-you ’d see [they]530-they are n’t if [I]0-i could tell [you]517-you about [our]525-we last summer holidays . Only [I]0-i must n’t . Thank [you]517-you very much . And can [you]517-you read the name ? ” “[517-you] Yes , [I]0-i can read it . ” “[0-i] Will [you]517-you tell it [us]525-we ? ” “[517-you] The name , ” said [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman , “[517-you] is [Ur Hekau Setcheh]152-ur hekau setcheh . ” “[152-ur hekau setcheh] [Ur Hekau Setcheh]152-ur hekau setcheh , ” repeated [Cyril]131-cyril . “[152-ur hekau setcheh] Thanks awfully . [I]0-i do hope [we]525-we have n’t taken up too much of [your]517-you time . ” “[0-i] Not at all , ” said [the gentleman]2364-the gentleman . “[0-i] And do let [me]0-i entreat [you]517-you to be very , very careful of that most valuable specimen . ” [They]525-we said “[0-i] thank [you]517-you ” in all the different polite ways [they]525-we could think of , and filed out of the door and down the stairs . [Anthea]133-anthea was last . Half‐way down to [the first landing]2386-the first landing [she]133-anthea turned and ran up again . The door was still open , and [the learned gentleman]2353-the learned gentleman and [the mummy‐case]2388-the mummy‐case were standing opposite to [each other]312-each other , and [both]2390-both looked as though [they]2390-both had stood like that for years . [The gentleman]2364-the gentleman started when [Anthea]133-anthea put [her]133-anthea hand on [his]0-i arm . “[0-i] [I]0-i hope [you]0-i wo n’t be cross and say it ’s not [my]0-i business , ” [she]133-anthea said , “[0-i] but do look at [your]0-i chop ! Do n’t [you]0-i think [you]0-i ought to eat it ? [Father]137-father forgets [his]137-father dinner sometimes when [he]137-father ’s writing , and [Mother]138-mother always says [I]0-i ought to remind [him]137-father if [she]138-mother ’s not at [home]357-home to do it [herself]138-mother , because it ’s so bad to miss [your]0-i regular meals . So [I]0-i thought perhaps [you]0-i would n’t mind [my]0-i reminding [you]0-i , because [you]0-i do n’t seem to have [anyone else]529-anyone else to do it . ” [She]533-my dear glanced at the mummy‐case ; it certainly did not look as though it would ever think of reminding [people]280-people of [their]280-people meals . [The learned gentleman]2353-the learned gentleman looked at [her]533-my dear for a moment before [he]2353-the learned gentleman said — “[0-i] Thank [you]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]533-my dear . It was a kindly thought . No , [I]0-i have n’t [anyone]283-anyone to remind [me]0-i about things like that . ” [He]2353-the learned gentleman sighed , and looked at the chop . “[283-anyone] It looks very nasty , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[283-anyone] Yes , ” [he]2353-the learned gentleman said , “[283-anyone] it does . [I]0-i ’ll eat it immediately , before [I]0-i forget . ” As [he]2353-the learned gentleman ate it [he]2353-the learned gentleman sighed more than once . Perhaps because the chop was nasty , perhaps because [he]2353-the learned gentleman longed for the charm which [the children]278-the children did not want to sell , perhaps because it was so long since [anyone]283-anyone cared whether [he]2353-the learned gentleman ate [his]2353-the learned gentleman chops or forgot them . [Anthea]133-anthea caught [the others]325-the others at the stair‐foot . [They]278-the children woke [the Psammead]136-the psammead , and it taught [them]278-the children exactly how to use the word of power , and to make the charm speak . [I]283-anyone am not going to tell [you]2397-you how this is done , because [you]2397-you might try to do it . And for [you]2397-you any such trying would be almost sure to end in disappointment . Because in the first place it is a thousand million to one against [your]2397-you ever getting hold of the right sort of charm , and if [you]2397-you did , there would be hardly any chance at all of [your]2397-you finding [a learned gentleman clever enough and kind enough to read the word]2398-a learned gentleman clever enough and kind enough to read the word for [you]2397-you . [The children]278-the children and [the Psammead]400-the psammead crouched in a circle on the floor — in [[the girls]311-the girls ’ bedroom]2402-the girls ’ bedroom , because in [the parlour]314-the parlour [they]278-the children might have been interrupted by [old Nurse]305-old nurse ’s coming in to lay the cloth for tea — and the charm was put in the middle of the circle . The sun shone splendidly outside , and [the room]2349-the room was very light . Through the open window came the hum and rattle of [London]2-london , and in [the street below]2406-the street below [they]278-the children could hear the voice of [the milkman]2407-the milkman . When all was ready , [the Psammead]136-the psammead signed to [Anthea]133-anthea to say the word . And [she]133-anthea said it . Instantly the whole light of all [the world]294-the world seemed to go out . [The room]2349-the room was dark . [The world outside]2410-the world outside was dark — darker than the darkest night that ever was . And all the sounds went out too , so that there was a silence deeper than any silence [you]2397-you have ever even dreamed of imagining . It was like being suddenly deaf and blind , only darker and quieter even than that . But before [the children]278-the children had got over the sudden shock of it enough to be frightened , a faint , beautiful light began to show in the middle of the circle , and at the same moment a faint , beautiful voice began to speak . The light was too small for [one]346-one to see anything by , and the voice was too small for [you]2397-you to hear what it said . [You]2397-you could just see the light and just hear the voice . But the light grew stronger . It was greeny , like glow‐worms ’ lamps , and it grew and grew till it was as though thousands and thousands of glow‐worms were signalling to [[their]278-the children winged sweethearts]2413-their winged sweethearts from the middle of the circle . And the voice grew , not so much in loudness as in sweetness ( though it grew louder , too ) , till it was so sweet that [you]2397-you wanted to cry with pleasure just at the sound of it . It was like nightingales , and [the sea]2414-the sea , and the fiddle , and the voice of [[your]2397-you mother]2415-your mother when [you]2397-you have been a long time away , and [she]2415-your mother meets [you]2397-you at the door when [you]2397-you get [home]357-home . And the voice said — “[283-anyone] Speak . What is it that [you]535-you would hear ? ” [I]283-anyone can not tell [you]2397-you what language the voice used . [I]283-anyone only know that [everyone present]2417-everyone present understood it perfectly . If [you]2397-you come to think of it , there must be some language that [everyone]319-everyone could understand , if [we]2419-we only knew what it was . Nor can [I]283-anyone tell [you]2397-you how the charm spoke , nor whether it was the charm that spoke , or some presence in the charm . [The children]278-the children could not have told [you]2397-you either . Indeed , [they]278-the children could not look at the charm while it was speaking , because the light was too bright . [They]278-the children looked instead at the green radiance on the faded Kidderminster carpet at the edge of the circle . [They]278-the children all felt very quiet , and not inclined to ask questions or fidget with [their]278-the children feet . For this was not like the things that had happened in [the country]290-the country when [the Psammead]136-the psammead had given [them]278-the children [their]278-the children wishes . That had been funny somehow , and this was not . It was something like Arabian Nights magic , and something like being in [church]2422-church . [No one]344-no one cared to speak . It was [Cyril]131-cyril who said at last — “[283-anyone] Please [we]536-we want to know where the other half of the charm is . ” “[283-anyone] The part of the Amulet which is lost , ” said [the beautiful voice]2424-the beautiful voice , “[283-anyone] was broken and ground into the dust of the shrine that held it . It and the pin that joined the two halves are themselves dust , and the dust is scattered over [many lands]537-many lands and sunk in [many seas]538-many seas . ” “[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i say ! ” murmured [Robert]132-robert , and a blank silence fell . “[0-i] Then it ’s all up ? ” said [Cyril]131-cyril at last ; “[0-i] it ’s no use [our]536-we looking for a thing that ’s smashed into dust , and the dust scattered all over [the place]539-the place . ” “[0-i] If [you]540-you would find it , ” said [the voice]2425-the voice , “[540-you] [You]540-you must seek it where it still is , perfect as ever . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t understand , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[0-i] In [the Past]20-the past [you]540-you may find it , ” said [the voice]2425-the voice . “[540-you] [I]0-i wish [we]536-we may find it , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . [The Psammead]136-the psammead whispered crossly , “[0-i] Do n’t [you]540-you understand ? The thing existed in [the Past]20-the past . If [you]540-you were in [the Past]20-the past , too , [you]540-you could find it . It ’s very difficult to make [you]540-you understand things . Time and space are only forms of thought . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i see , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[0-i] No , [you]540-you do n’t , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , “[540-you] and it does n’t matter if [you]540-you do n’t , either . What [I]0-i mean is that if [you]540-you were only made the right way , [you]540-you could see everything happening in [the same place]541-the same place at the same time . Now do [you]540-you see ? ” “[540-you] [I]0-i ’m afraid [I]0-i do n’t , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea ; “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m sorry [I]0-i ’m so stupid . ” “[0-i] Well , at any rate , [you]540-you see this . That lost half of the Amulet is in the Past . Therefore it ’s in the Past [we]542-we must look for it . [I]0-i must n’t speak to the charm [myself]0-i . Ask it things ! Find out ! ” “[542-we] Where can [we]542-we find the other part of [you]540-you ? ” asked [Cyril]131-cyril obediently . “[542-we] In the Past , ” said [the voice]2425-the voice . “[542-we] What part of the Past ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i may not tell [you]540-you . If [you]540-you will choose a time , [I]0-i will take [you]540-you to the place that then held it . [You]540-you [yourselves]540-you must find it . ” “[540-you] When did [you]540-you see it last ? ” asked [Anthea—“I]153-anthea—“i[540-you] mean , when was it taken away from [you]540-you ? ” [The beautiful voice]2424-the beautiful voice answered — “[540-you] That was thousands of years ago . The Amulet was perfect then , and lay in [a shrine]543-a shrine , the last of [many shrines]544-many shrines , and [I]0-i worked wonders . Then came [strange men with strange weapons]545-strange men with strange weapons and destroyed [[my]0-i shrine]546-my shrine , and the Amulet [they]545-strange men with strange weapons bore away with [many captives]547-many captives . But of these , one , [[my]0-i priest]548-my priest , knew the word of power , and spoke it for [me]0-i , so that the Amulet became invisible , and thus returned to [[my]0-i shrine]546-my shrine , but [the shrine]550-the shrine was broken down , and ere any magic could rebuild it , [one]346-one spoke a word before which [my]0-i power bowed down and was still . And the Amulet lay there , still perfect , but enslaved . Then one coming with stones to rebuild [the shrine]550-the shrine , dropped a hewn stone on the Amulet as it lay , and one half was sundered from the other . [I]0-i had no power to seek for that which was lost . And there being none to speak the word of power , [I]0-i could not rejoin it . So the Amulet lay in the dust of [the desert]553-the desert many thousand years , and at last came [a small man]554-a small man , [a conqueror with [an army]556-an army]555-a conqueror with an army , and after [him]554-a small man a crowd of [men who sought to seem wise]557-men who sought to seem wise , and one of these found half the Amulet and brought it to [this land]558-this land . But [none could read the name]559-none could read the name . So [I]0-i lay still . And [this man]560-this man dying and [[his]560-this man son]561-his son after [him]560-this man , the Amulet was sold by [those who came after]562-those who came after to [a merchant]563-a merchant , and from [him]563-a merchant [you]564-you bought it , and it is here , and now , the name of power having been spoken , [I]0-i also am here . ” This is what the voice said . [I]565-you think it must have meant [Napoleon]154-napoleon by [the small man]2429-the small man , [the conqueror]2430-the conqueror . Because [I]565-you know [I]565-you have been told that [he]2429-the small man took [an army]556-an army to [Egypt]21-egypt , and that afterwards [a lot of wise people]2432-a lot of wise people went grubbing in the sand , and fished up all sorts of wonderful things , older than [you]564-you would think possible . And of these [I]565-you believe this charm to have been one , and [the most wonderful one of all]2433-the most wonderful one of all . [Everyone]319-everyone listened : and [everyone]319-everyone tried to think . It is not easy to do this clearly when [you]564-you have been listening to the kind of talk [I]565-you have told [you]564-you about . At last [Robert]132-robert said — “[565-you] Can [you]565-you take [us]566-us into [the Past]20-the past — to [the shrine where [you]565-you and the other thing were together]567-the shrine where you and the other thing were together . If [you]565-you could take [us]566-us [there]321-there , [we]566-us might find the other part still there after all these thousands of years . ” “[565-you] Still there ? silly ! ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[565-you] Do n’t [you]565-you see , if [we]566-us go back into [the Past]20-the past it wo n’t be thousands of years ago . It will be now for [us]566-us — won’t it ? ” [He]131-cyril appealed to [the Psammead]136-the psammead , who said — “[565-you] [You]565-you ’re not so far off the idea as [you]565-you usually are ! ” “[565-you] Well , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , “[565-you] will [you]565-you take [us]566-us back to when there was [a shrine]543-a shrine and [you]565-you were safe in [it]543-a shrine — all of [you]565-you ? ” “[565-you] Yes , ” said the voice . “[565-you] [You]565-you must hold [me]0-i up , and speak the word of power , and one by one , beginning with [the first‐born]570-the first‐born , [you]565-you shall pass through [me]0-i into [the Past]20-the past . But let [the last that passes]571-the last that passes be the one that holds [me]0-i , and let [him]571-the last that passes not lose [his]571-the last that passes hold , lest [you]565-you lose [me]0-i , and so remain in [the Past]20-the past for ever . ” “[571-the last that passes] That ’s a nasty idea , ” said [Robert]132-robert . “[571-the last that passes] When [you]565-you desire to return , ” [the beautiful voice]2424-the beautiful voice went on , “[565-you] hold [me]0-i up towards [the East]572-the east , and speak the word . Then , passing through [me]0-i , [you]565-you shall return to this time and it shall be the present to [you]565-you . ” “[565-you] But how — ” A bell rang loudly . “[565-you] Oh crikey ! ” exclaimed [Robert]132-robert , “[565-you] that ’s tea ! Will [you]565-you please make it proper daylight again so that [we]573-we can go down . And thank [you]565-you so much for all [your]565-you kindness . ” “[565-you] [We]573-we ’ve enjoyed [ourselves]573-we very much indeed , thank [you]565-you ! ” added [Anthea]133-anthea politely . The beautiful light faded slowly . The great darkness and silence came and these suddenly changed to the dazzlement of day and the great soft , rustling sound of [London]2-london , that is like some vast beast turning over in its sleep . [The children]278-the children rubbed [their]278-the children eyes , [the Psammead]136-the psammead ran quickly to [its]136-the psammead sandy bath , and [the others]325-the others went down to tea . And until the cups were actually filled tea seemed less real than the beautiful voice and the greeny light . After tea [Anthea]133-anthea persuaded [the others]325-the others to allow [her]133-anthea to hang the charm round [her]133-anthea neck with a piece of string . “[565-you] It would be so awful if it got lost , ” [she]133-anthea said : “[565-you] it might get lost anywhere , [you]565-you know , and it would be rather beastly for [us]573-we to have to stay in [the Past]20-the past for ever and ever , would n’t it ? ” NEXT morning [Anthea]133-anthea got [old Nurse]142-old nurse to allow [her]133-anthea to take up [the “[565-you] poor learned gentleman]2352-the “ poor learned gentleman ’s ” breakfast . [He]565-you did not recognize [her]133-anthea at first , but when [he]565-you did [he]565-you was vaguely pleased to see [her]133-anthea . “[565-you] [You]565-you see [I]0-i ’m wearing the charm round [my]0-i neck , ” [she]133-anthea said ; “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m taking care of it — like [you]565-you told [us]573-we to . ” “[0-i] That ’s right , ” said [he]565-you ; “[0-i] did [you]0-i have a good game last night ? ” “[0-i] [You]565-you will eat [your]565-you breakfast before it ’s cold , wo n’t [you]565-you ? ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[0-i] Yes , [we]573-we had a splendid time . The charm made it all dark , and then greeny light , and then it spoke . Oh ! [I]0-i wish [you]565-you could have heard it — it was such a darling voice — and it told [us]573-we the other half of it was lost in [the Past]20-the past , so of course [we]573-we shall have to look for it there ! ” [The learned gentleman]2353-the learned gentleman rubbed [his]2353-the learned gentleman hair with both hands and looked anxiously at [Anthea]133-anthea . “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose it ’s natural — youthful imagina‐ tion and so forth , ” [he]2353-the learned gentleman said . “[0-i] Yet [someone]331-someone must have ... Who told [you]565-you that some part of the charm was missing ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t tell [you]0-i , ” [she]133-anthea said . “[0-i] [I]0-i know it seems most awfully rude , especially after [you]0-i being so kind about telling [us]573-we the name of power , and all that , but really , [I]0-i ’m not allowed to tell [anybody]575-anybody anything about the — the — the person who told [me]0-i . [You]0-i wo n’t forget [your]0-i breakfast , will [you]0-i ? ” [The learned gentleman]2353-the learned gentleman smiled feebly and then frowned — not a cross‐frown , but a puzzle‐frown . “[0-i] Thank [you]0-i , ” [he]2353-the learned gentleman said , “[0-i] [I]0-i shall always be pleased if [you]0-i ’ll look in — any time [you]0-i ’re passing [you]0-i know — at least ... ” “[0-i] [I]0-i will , ” [she]2353-the learned gentleman said ; “[0-i] goodbye . [I]0-i ’ll always tell [you]0-i anything [I]0-i may tell . ” [He]2353-the learned gentleman had not had many adventures with [children]437-children in [them]437-children , and [he]2353-the learned gentleman wondered whether [all children]2444-all children were like these . [He]2353-the learned gentleman spent quite five minutes in wondering before [he]2353-the learned gentleman settled down to the fifty‐second chapter of [his]2353-the learned gentleman great book on “[0-i] the Secret Rites of [the Priests of [Amen Rā]22-amen rā]576-the priests of amen rā . ” It is no use to pretend that [the children]278-the children did not feel a good deal of agitation at the thought of going through the charm into [the Past]20-the past . That idea , that perhaps [they]278-the children might stay in [the Past]20-the past and never get back again , was anything but pleasing . Yet [no one]344-no one would have dared to suggest that the charm should not be used ; and though [each]2447-each was in [its]2447-each heart very frightened indeed , [they]278-the children would all have joined in jeering at the cowardice of any one of [them]278-the children who should have uttered the timid but natural suggestion , “[576-the priests of amen rā] Do n’t let ’s ! ” It seemed necessary to make arrangements for being out all day , for there was no reason to suppose that the sound of the dinner‐bell would be able to reach back into the Past , and it seemed unwise to excite [old Nurse]142-old nurse ’s curiosity when nothing [they]278-the children could say — not even the truth — could in any way satisfy it . [They]278-the children were all very proud to think how well [they]278-the children had understood what the charm and the Psammead had said about Time and Space and things like that , and [they]278-the children were perfectly certain that it would be quite impossible to make [old Nurse]142-old nurse understand a single word of it . So [they]278-the children merely asked [her]142-old nurse to let [them]278-the children take [their]278-the children dinner out into [Regent ’s Park]23-regent ’s park — and this , with the implied cold mutton and tomatoes , was readily granted . “[577-you] [You]577-you can get [yourselves]577-you some buns or sponge‐cakes , or whatever [you]577-you fancy‐like , ” said [old Nurse]142-old nurse , giving [Cyril]131-cyril a shilling . “[577-you] Do n’t go getting jam‐tarts , now — so messy at the best of times , and without forks and plates ruination to [your]577-you clothes , besides [your]577-you not being able to wash [your]577-you hands and faces afterwards . ” So [Cyril]131-cyril took the shilling , and [they]278-the children all started off . [They]278-the children went round by [the Tottenham Court Road]2332-the tottenham court road to buy a piece of waterproof sheeting to put over [the Psammead]136-the psammead in case it should be raining in [the Past]20-the past when [they]278-the children got [there]321-there . For it is almost certain death to a Psammead to get wet . The sun was shining very brightly , and even [London]2-london looked pretty . [Women]2450-women were selling roses from big baskets‐full , and [Anthea]133-anthea bought four roses , one each , for [herself]133-anthea and the others . They were red roses and smelt of summer — the kind of roses [you]577-you always want so desperately at about Christmas‐time when [you]577-you can only get mistletoe , which is pale right through to its very scent , and holly which pricks [your]577-you nose if [you]577-you try to smell it . So now [everyone]319-everyone had a rose in its buttonhole , and soon [everyone]319-everyone was sitting on the grass in [Regent ’s Park]23-regent ’s park under trees whose leaves would have been clean , clear green in [the country]290-the country , but here were dusty and yellowish , and brown at the edges . “[578-we] [We]578-we ’ve got to go on with it , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , “[578-we] and as [the eldest]579-the eldest has to go first , [you]580-you ’ll have to be last , [Jane]134-jane . [You]580-you quite understand about holding on to the charm as [you]580-you go through , do n’t [you]580-you , [Pussy]155-pussy ? ” “[155-pussy] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i had n’t got to be last , ” said [Jane]134-jane . “[0-i] [You]580-you shall carry the Psammead if [you]580-you like , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[580-you] That is , ” [she]133-anthea added , remembering the beast ’s queer temper , “[580-you] if it ’ll let [you]580-you . ” The Psammead , however , was unexpectedly amiable . “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t mind , ” it said , “[0-i] who carries [me]0-i , so long as it does n’t drop [me]0-i . [I]0-i ca n’t bear being dropped . ” [Jane]134-jane with trembling hands took [the Psammead]136-the psammead and its fish‐basket under one arm . The charm ’s long string was hung round [her]134-jane neck . Then [they]2454-they all stood up . [Jane]134-jane held out the charm at arm ’s length , and [Cyril]131-cyril solemnly pronounced the word of power . As [he]131-cyril spoke it the charm grew tall and broad , and [he]131-cyril saw that [Jane]134-jane was just holding on to the edge of a great red arch of very curious shape . The opening of the arch was small , but [Cyril]131-cyril saw that [he]131-cyril could go through it . All round and beyond the arch were the faded trees and trampled grass of [Regent ’s Park]23-regent ’s park , where [the little ragged children]2455-the little ragged children were playing Ring o ’ Roses . But through the opening of it shone a blaze of blue and yellow and red . [Cyril]131-cyril drew a long breath and stiffened [his]131-cyril legs so that [the others]325-the others should not see that [his]131-cyril knees were trembling and almost knocking together . “[0-i] Here goes ! ” [he]131-cyril said , and , stepping up through the arch , disappeared . Then followed [Anthea]133-anthea . [Robert]132-robert , coming next , held fast , at [Anthea]133-anthea ’s suggestion , to the sleeve of [Jane]134-jane , who was thus dragged safely through the arch . And as soon as [they]2454-they were on the other side of the arch there was [no more arch]2457-no more arch at all and [no more Regent ’s Park]2458-no more regent ’s park either , only the charm in [Jane]134-jane ’s hand , and it was its proper size again . [They]2454-they were now in a light so bright that [they]2454-they winked and blinked and rubbed [their]2454-they eyes . During this dazzling interval [Anthea]133-anthea felt for the charm and pushed it inside [Jane]134-jane ’s frock , so that it might be quite safe . When [their]2454-they eyes got used to the new wonderful light [the children]278-the children looked around [them]2454-they . The sky was very , very blue , and it sparkled and glittered and dazzled like the sea at [home]357-home when the sun shines on [it]2461-it . [They]278-the children were standing on [a little clearing in [a thick , low forest]2463-a thick , low forest]2462-a little clearing in a thick , low forest ; there were trees and shrubs and a close , thorny , tangly undergrowth . In front of [them]278-the children stretched a bank of strange black mud , then came the browny‐yellowy shining ribbon of [a river]2464-a river . Then more dry , caked mud and more greeny‐browny jungle . The only things that told that [human people]2465-human people had been there were [the clearing]2466-the clearing , a path that led to it , and an odd arrangement of cut reeds in [the river]2467-the river . [They]278-the children looked at [each other]312-each other . “[0-i] Well ! ” said [Robert]132-robert , “[0-i] this is a change of air ! ” It was . The air was hotter than [they]278-the children could have imagined , even in [London]2-london in [August]26-august . “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i knew where [we]581-we were , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[0-i] Here ’s [a river]2464-a river , now — [I]0-i wonder whether it ’s [the Amazon]27-the amazon or [the Tiber]28-the tiber , or what . ” “[0-i] It ’s [the Nile]29-the nile , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , looking out of the fish‐bag . “[0-i] Then this is [Egypt]21-egypt , ” said [Robert]132-robert , who had once taken a geography prize . “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t see any crocodiles , ” [Cyril]131-cyril objected . [His]0-i prize had been for natural history . [The Psammead]136-the psammead reached out a hairy arm from its basket and pointed to a heap of mud at the edge of [the water]2469-the water . “[0-i] What do [you]583-you call that ? ” it said ; and as it spoke the heap of mud slid into [the river]2467-the river just as a slab of badly mixed mortar will slip from [a bricklayer]2471-a bricklayer ’s trowel . “[583-you] Oh ! ” said [everybody]2317-everybody . There was a crashing among the reeds on [the other side of [the water]2469-the water]2473-the other side of the water . “[583-you] And there ’s a river‐horse ! ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , as a great beast like an enormous slaty‐blue slug showed itself against the black bank on [the far side of [the stream]2476-the stream]2475-the far side of the stream . “[583-you] It ’s a hippopotamus , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril ; “[0-i] it seems much more real somehow than the one at [the Zoo]417-the zoo , does n’t it ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m glad it ’s being real on [the other side of [the river]2467-the river]585-the other side of the river , ” said [Jane]134-jane . And now there was a crackling of reeds and twigs behind [them]587-us . This was horrible . Of course it might be another hippopotamus , or a crocodile , or a lion — or , in fact , almost anything . “[0-i] Keep [your]0-i hand on the charm , [Jane]134-jane , ” said [Robert]132-robert hastily . “[134-jane] [We]587-us ought to have a means of escape handy . [I]0-i ’m dead certain this is the sort of place where simply anything might happen to [us]587-us . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i believe a hippopotamus is going to happen to [us]587-us , ” said [Jane—“a[0-i] very , very big one]2477-jane—“a very , very big one . ” [They]587-us had all turned to face the danger . “[0-i] Do n’t be silly little duffers , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead in [its]136-the psammead friendly , informal way ; “[0-i] it ’s not a river‐horse . [It]588-she ’s [a human]589-a human . ” [It]588-she was . [It]588-she was [a girl]2478-a girl — of about [Anthea]133-anthea ’s age . [Her]588-she hair was short and fair , and though [her]588-she skin was tanned by the sun , [you]2479-you could see that it would have been fair too if it had had a chance . [She]588-she had every chance of being tanned , for [she]588-she had no clothes to speak of , and [the four English children , carefully dressed in frocks , hats , shoes , stockings , coats , collars , and all the rest of it]2480-the four english children , carefully dressed in frocks , hats , shoes , stockings , coats , collars , and all the rest of it , envied [her]588-she more than any words of theirs or of [mine]2481-mine could possibly say . There was no doubt that [hers]588-she was the right costume for that climate . [She]588-she carried a pot on [her]588-she head , of red and black earthenware . [She]588-she did not see [the children , who shrank back against the edge of]2482-the children , who shrank back against the edge of [the jungle]2483-the jungle , and [she]588-she went forward to [the brink of [the river]2467-the river]2484-the brink of the river to fill [her]588-she pitcher . As [she]588-she went [she]588-she made a strange sort of droning , humming , melancholy noise all on two notes . [Anthea]133-anthea could not help thinking that perhaps [the girl]2486-the girl thought this noise was singing . [The girl]2486-the girl filled the pitcher and set it down by [the river brink]2488-the river brink . Then [she]2486-the girl waded into the water and stooped over the circle of cut reeds . [She]2486-the girl pulled half a dozen fine fish out of the water within the reeds , killing each as [she]2486-the girl took it out , and threading it on a long osier that [she]2486-the girl carried . Then [she]2486-the girl knotted the osier , hung it on [her]2486-the girl arm , picked up the pitcher , and turned to come back . And as [she]2486-the girl turned [she]2486-the girl saw [the four children]309-the four children . The white dresses of [Jane]134-jane and [Anthea]133-anthea stood out like snow against the dark forest background . [She]588-she screamed and the pitcher fell , and the water was spilled out over the hard mud surface and over the fish , which had fallen too . Then the water slowly trickled away into the deep cracks . “[589-a human] Do n’t be frightened , ” [Anthea]133-anthea cried , “[590-we] [we]590-we wo n’t hurt [you]591-i . ” “[590-we] Who are [you]591-i ? ” said [the girl]2486-the girl . Now , once for all , [I]591-i am not going to be bothered to tell [you]2491-you how it was that [the girl]2486-the girl could understand [Anthea]133-anthea and [Anthea]133-anthea could understand [the girl]2486-the girl . [You]2491-you , at any rate , would not understand [me]591-i , if [I]591-i tried to explain it , any more than [you]2491-you can understand about time and space being only forms of thought . [You]2491-you may think what [you]2491-you like . Perhaps [the children]278-the children had found out the universal language which [everyone]319-everyone can understand , and which [wise men so far]2496-wise men so far have not found . [You]2491-you will have noticed long ago that [they]278-the children were [singularly lucky children]2497-singularly lucky children , and [they]278-the children may have had this piece of luck as well as [others]2498-others . Or it may have been that ... but why pursue the question further ? The fact remains that in all [their]278-the children adventures the muddle‐headed inventions which [we]2499-we call foreign languages never bothered [them]278-the children in the least . [They]278-the children could always understand and be under‐ stood . If [you]2491-you can explain this , please do . [I]591-i daresay [I]591-i could understand [your]2491-you explanation , though [you]2491-you could never understand [mine]591-i . So when [the girl]2486-the girl said , “[591-i] Who are [you]592-you ? ” [everyone]319-everyone understood at once , and [Anthea]133-anthea replied — “[593-us] [We]593-us are [children]437-children — just like [you]592-you . Do n’t be frightened . Wo n’t [you]592-you show [us]593-us where [you]592-you live ? ” [Jane]134-jane put [her]134-jane face right into the Psammead ’s basket , and burrowed [her]134-jane mouth into its fur to whisper — “[592-you] Is it safe ? Wo n’t [they]595-they eat [us]593-us ? Are [they]595-they cannibals ? ” [The Psammead]400-the psammead shrugged its fur . “[595-they] Do n’t make [your]592-you voice buzz like that , it tickles [my]0-i ears , ” it said rather crossly . “[592-you] [You]592-you can always get back to [Regent ’s Park]23-regent ’s park in time if [you]592-you keep fast hold of the charm , ” it said . [The strange girl]2503-the strange girl was trembling with fright . [Anthea]133-anthea had a bangle on [her]133-anthea arm . It was a sevenpenny‐halfpenny trumpery brass thing that pretended to be silver ; it had a glass heart of turquoise blue hanging from it , and it was the gift of the maid‐of‐all‐work at [the Fitzroy Street house]2504-the fitzroy street house . “[592-you] Here , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea , “[592-you] this is for [you]592-you . That is to show [we]593-us will not hurt [you]592-you . And if [you]592-you take it [I]0-i shall know that [you]592-you wo n’t hurt [us]593-us . ” [The girl]2486-the girl held out [her]2486-the girl hand . [Anthea]133-anthea slid the bangle over it , and [the girl]2486-the girl ’s face lighted up with the joy of possession . “[592-you] Come , ” [she]133-anthea said , looking lovingly at the bangle ; “[592-you] it is peace between [[your]592-you house]596-your house and [mine]0-i . ” [She]133-anthea picked up [her]133-anthea fish and pitcher and led the way up [the narrow path by which [she]133-anthea had come]2507-the narrow path by which she had come , and [the others]325-the others followed . “[592-you] This is something like ! ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , trying to be brave . “[592-you] Yes ! ” said [Robert]132-robert , also assuming a boldness [he]132-robert was far from feeling , “[592-you] this really and truly is an adventure ! Its being in the Past makes it quite different from the Phœnix and [Carpet]30-carpet happenings . ” The belt of thick , growing acacia trees and shrubs — mostly prickly and unpleasant‐looking — seemed about half a mile across . [The path]2509-the path was narrow and the wood dark . At last , ahead , daylight shone through the boughs and leaves . [The whole party]2268-the whole party suddenly came out of the wood ’s shadow into the glare of the sunlight that shone on a great stretch of yellow sand , dotted with heaps of grey rocks where spiky cactus plants showed gaudy crimson and pink flowers among their shabby , sand‐peppered leaves . Away to the right was something that looked like a grey‐brown hedge , and from beyond it blue smoke went up to the bluer sky . And over all the sun shone till [you]2511-you could hardly bear [your]2511-you clothes . “[592-you] That is where [I]0-i live , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl pointing . “[0-i] [I]0-i wo n’t go , ” whispered [Jane]134-jane into the basket , “[0-i] unless [you]592-you say it ’s all right . ” [The Psammead]136-the psammead ought to have been touched by this proof of confidence . Perhaps , however , it looked upon it as a proof of doubt , for it merely snarled — “[592-you] If [you]0-i do n’t go now [I]0-i ’ll never help [you]0-i again . ” “[0-i] Oh , ” whispered [Anthea]133-anthea , “[134-jane] [dear Jane]134-jane , do n’t ! Think of [Father]137-father and [Mother]138-mother and all of [us]597-they getting [our]597-they heart ’s desire . And [we]597-they can go back any minute . Come on ! ” “[136-the psammead] Besides , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , in a low voice , “[136-the psammead] [the Psammead]136-the psammead must know there ’s no danger or it would n’t go . It ’s not so over and above brave itself . Come on ! ” This [Jane]134-jane at last consented to do . As [they]597-they got nearer to the browny fence [they]597-they saw that it was a great hedge about eight feet high , made of piled‐up thorn bushes . “[136-the psammead] What ’s that for ? ” asked [Cyril]131-cyril . “[136-the psammead] To keep out foes and wild beasts , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl . “[0-i] [I]0-i should think it ought to , too , ” said [he]0-i . “[0-i] Why , some of the thorns are as long as [my]0-i foot . ” There was an opening in the hedge , and [they]597-they followed [the girl]2486-the girl through it . A little way further on was another hedge , not so high , also of dry thorn bushes , very prickly and spiteful‐looking , and within this was [a sort of village of [huts]2516-huts]2515-a sort of village of huts . There were [no gardens]2517-no gardens and [no roads]2518-no roads . Just huts built of wood and twigs and clay , and roofed with great palm‐leaves , dumped down anywhere . The doors of [these houses]2519-these houses were very low , like the doors of dog‐kennels . The ground between [them]2519-these houses was not paths or [streets]2520-streets , but just yellow sand trampled very hard and smooth . In [the middle of [the village]2522-the village]2521-the middle of the village there was a hedge that enclosed what seemed to be a piece of ground about as big as [[their]597-they own garden]2523-their own garden in [Camden Town]11-camden town . No sooner were [the children]278-the children well within the inner thorn hedge than [dozens of [men]2526-men and [women]2450-women and [children]437-children]2525-dozens of men and women and children came crowding round from behind and inside [the huts]2529-the huts . [The girl]2486-the girl stood protectingly in front of [the four children]309-the four children , and said — “[598-they] [They]598-they are [wonder‐children]599-wonder‐children from beyond [the desert]553-the desert . [They]598-they bring marvellous gifts , and [I]0-i have said that it is peace between [us]601-we and [them]598-they . ” [She]2486-the girl held out [her]2486-the girl arm with the Lowther Arcade bangle on it . [The children from [London]2-london]2532-the children from london , where nothing now surprises [anyone]283-anyone , had never before seen [so many people]2534-so many people look so astonished . [They]2532-the children from london crowded round [the children]278-the children , touching [their]278-the children clothes , [their]278-the children shoes , the buttons on [the boys]313-the boys ’ jackets , and the coral of [the girls]311-the girls ’ necklaces . “[0-i] Do say something , ” whispered [Anthea]133-anthea . “[0-i] [We]601-we come , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , with some dim remembrance of a dreadful day when [he]131-cyril had had to wait in [an outer office]2538-an outer office while [[his]131-cyril father]2539-his father interviewed [a solicitor]2540-a solicitor , and there had been nothing to read but the Daily Telegraph — “[601-we] [we]601-we come from [the world where the sun never sets]602-the world where the sun never sets . And peace with honour is what [we]601-we want . [We]601-we are [the great Anglo‐Saxon or conquering race]603-the great anglo‐saxon or conquering race . Not that [we]601-we want to conquer [you]604-your , ” [he]131-cyril added hastily . “[601-we] [We]601-we only want to look at [[your]604-your houses]605-your houses and [your]604-your — well , at all [you]604-your ’ve got [here]2247-here , and then [we]601-we shall return to [[our]601-we own place]607-our own place , and tell of all that [we]601-we have seen so that [your]604-your name may be famed . ” [Cyril]131-cyril ’s speech did n’t keep [the crowd]2541-the crowd from pressing round and looking as eagerly as ever at the clothing of [the children]278-the children . [Anthea]133-anthea had an idea that [these people]2543-these people had never seen woven stuff before , and [she]133-anthea saw how wonderful and strange it must seem to [people who had never had any clothes but the skins of beasts]2544-people who had never had any clothes but the skins of beasts . The sewing , too , of modern clothes seemed to astonish [them]2543-these people very much . [They]2543-these people must have been able to sew [themselves]2543-these people , by the way , for [men who seemed to be [the chiefs]2546-the chiefs]2545-men who seemed to be the chiefs wore knickerbockers of goat‐skin or deer‐skin , fastened round the waist with twisted strips of hide . And [the women]2547-the women wore long skimpy skirts of animals ’ skins . [The people]2548-the people were not very tall , [their]2548-the people hair was fair , and [men]2526-men and [women]2450-women both had it short . [Their]2548-the people eyes were blue , and that seemed odd in [Egypt]21-egypt . [Most of [them]2548-the people]2551-most of them were tattooed like [sailors]2552-sailors , only more roughly . “[601-we] What is this ? What is this ? ” [they]2548-the people kept asking touching [the children]278-the children ’s clothes curiously . [Anthea]133-anthea hastily took off [Jane]134-jane ’s frilly lace collar and handed it to the woman who seemed most friendly . “[601-we] Take this , ” [she]133-anthea said , “[601-we] and look at it . And leave [us]608-us alone . [We]608-us want to talk among [ourselves]608-us . ” [She]133-anthea spoke in the tone of authority which [she]133-anthea had always found successful when [she]133-anthea had not time to coax [[her]133-anthea baby brother]2554-her baby brother to do as [he]2554-her baby brother was told . The tone was just as successful now . [The children]278-the children were left together and [the crowd]2541-the crowd retreated . [It]2541-the crowd paused a dozen yards away to look at the lace collar and to go on talking as hard as it could . [The children]278-the children will never know what [those people]2558-those people said , though [they]278-the children knew well enough that [they]278-the children , [the four strangers]2559-the four strangers , were the subject of the talk . [They]278-the children tried to comfort [themselves]278-the children by remembering [the girl]2486-the girl ’s promise of friendliness , but of course the thought of the charm was more comfortable than anything else . [They]278-the children sat down on the sand in the shadow of the hedged‐round place in [the middle of [the village]2522-the village]2521-the middle of the village , and now for the first time [they]278-the children were able to look about [them]278-the children and to see something more than [a crowd of eager , curious faces]2563-a crowd of eager , curious faces . [They]278-the children here noticed that [the women]2547-the women wore necklaces made of beads of different coloured stone , and from these hung pendants of odd , strange shapes , and some of [them]2547-the women had bracelets of ivory and flint . “[0-i] [I]0-i say , ” said [Robert]132-robert , “[0-i] what a lot [we]609-we could teach [them]610-they if [we]609-we stayed [here]2247-here ! ” “[610-they] [I]0-i expect [they]610-they could teach [us]609-we something too , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[610-they] Did [you]612-you notice that flint bracelet [the woman]613-the woman had that [Anthea]133-anthea gave the collar to ? That must have taken some making . Look here , [they]610-they ’ll get suspicious if [we]609-we talk among [ourselves]609-we , and [I]0-i do want to know about how [they]610-they do things . Let ’s get [the girl]2486-the girl to show [us]609-we round , and [we]609-we can be thinking about how to get the Amulet at the same time . Only mind , [we]609-we must keep together . ” [Anthea]133-anthea beckoned to [the girl]2486-the girl , who was standing a little way off looking wistfully at [them]609-we , and [she]2486-the girl came gladly . “[2486-the girl] Tell [us]609-we how [you]612-you make the bracelets , the stone ones , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[2486-the girl] With other stones , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl ; “[2486-the girl] [the men]615-the men make [them]616-them ; [we]609-we have [men of special skill in such work]617-men of special skill in such work . ” “[0-i] Have n’t [you]0-i any iron tools ? ” “[0-i] Iron , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl , “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know what [you]0-i mean . ” It was the first word [she]2486-the girl had not understood . “[0-i] Are all [your]612-you tools of flint ? ” asked [Cyril]131-cyril . “[0-i] Of course , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl , opening [her]2486-the girl eyes wide . [I]0-i wish [I]0-i had time to tell [you]0-i of that talk . [The English children]2569-the english children wanted to hear all about [this new place]2570-this new place , but [they]2569-the english children also wanted to tell of [[their]2569-the english children [own country]2572-own country]2571-their own country . It was like when [you]2573-you come back from [your]2573-you holidays and [you]2573-you want to hear and to tell everything at the same time . As the talk went on there were more and more words that [the girl]2486-the girl could not understand , and [the children]278-the children soon gave up the attempt to explain to [her]2486-the girl what [[their]278-the children own country]2571-their own country was like , when [they]278-the children began to see how very few of the things [they]278-the children had always thought [they]278-the children could not do without were really at all necessary to life . [The girl]2486-the girl showed [them]278-the children how [the huts]2529-the huts were made — indeed , as one was being made that very day [she]2486-the girl took [them]278-the children to look at it . The way of building was very different from [ours]2579-ours . [The men]615-the men stuck long pieces of wood into a piece of ground the size of [the hut [they]615-the men wanted to make]2581-the hut they wanted to make . These were about eight inches apart ; then [they]615-the men put in another row about eight inches away from the first , and then a third row still further out . Then all the space between was filled up with small branches and twigs , and then daubed over with black mud worked with the feet till it was soft and sticky like putty . [The girl]2486-the girl told [them]278-the children how [the men]615-the men went hunting with flint spears and arrows , and how [they]615-the men made boats with reeds and clay . Then [she]2486-the girl explained the reed thing in [the river]2467-the river that [she]2486-the girl had taken the fish out of . It was a fish‐trap — just a ring of reeds set up in the water with only one little opening in it , and in this opening , just below the water , were stuck reeds slanting the way of [the river]2467-the river ’s flow , so that [the fish]2586-the fish , when [they]2586-the fish had swum sillily in , sillily could n’t get out again . [She]2486-the girl showed [them]278-the children the clay pots and jars and platters , some of them ornamented with black and red patterns , and the most wonderful things made of flint and different sorts of stone , beads , and ornaments , and tools and weapons of all sorts and kinds . “[0-i] It is really wonderful , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril patronizingly , “[618-you] when [you]618-you consider that it ’s all eight thousand years ago — ” “[618-you] [I]0-i do n’t understand [you]618-you , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl . “[0-i] It is n’t eight thousand years ago , ” whispered [Jane]134-jane . “[0-i] It ’s now — and that ’s just what [I]0-i do n’t like about it . [I]0-i say , do let ’s get [home]357-home again before anything more happens . [You]618-you can see for [yourselves]618-you the charm is n’t here . ” “[618-you] What ’s in that place in the middle ? ” asked [Anthea]133-anthea , struck by a sudden thought , and pointing to the fence . “[618-you] That ’s [the secret sacred place]620-the secret sacred place , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl in a whisper . “[344-no one] [No one]344-no one knows what is there . There are many walls , and inside the insidest one It is , but [no one]344-no one knows what It is except [the headsmen]623-the headsmen . ” “[623-the headsmen] [I]0-i believe [you]618-you know , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , looking at [her]2486-the girl very hard . “[618-you] [I]0-i ’ll give [you]618-you this if [you]618-you ’ll tell [me]0-i , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea taking off a bead‐ring which had already been much admired . “[0-i] Yes , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl , catching eagerly at the ring . “[0-i] [[My]0-i father]624-my father is one of the heads , and [I]0-i know a water charm to make [him]624-my father talk in [his]624-my father sleep . And [he]624-my father has spoken . [I]0-i will tell [you]618-you . But if [they]623-the headsmen know [I]0-i have told [you]618-you [they]623-the headsmen will kill [me]0-i . In the insidest inside there is a stone box , and in it there is the Amulet . [None]625-none knows whence it came . It came from very far away . ” “[618-you] Have [you]618-you seen it ? ” asked [Anthea]133-anthea . [The girl]2486-the girl nodded . “[618-you] Is it anything like this ? ” asked [Jane]134-jane , rashly producing the charm . [The girl]2486-the girl ’s face turned a sickly greenish white . “[618-you] Hide it , hide it , ” [she]2486-the girl whispered . “[618-you] [You]618-you must put it back . If [they]623-the headsmen see it [they]623-the headsmen will kill [us]626-us all . [You]618-you for taking it , and [me]0-i for knowing that there was such a thing . Oh , woe — woe ! why did [you]618-you ever come here ? ” “[618-you] Do n’t be frightened , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril . “[623-the headsmen] [they]623-the headsmen sha n’t know . [Jane]134-jane , do n’t [you]134-jane be such [a little jack‐ape]627-a little jack‐ape again — that ’s all . [You]134-jane see what will happen if [you]134-jane do . Now , tell [me]0-i — ” [He]131-cyril turned to [the girl]2486-the girl , but before [he]131-cyril had time to speak the question there was a loud shout , and [a man]451-a man bounded in through the opening in the thorn‐hedge . “[0-i] [Many foes]628-many foes are upon [us]626-us ! ” [he]451-a man cried . “[628-many foes] Make ready the defences ! ” [His]451-a man breath only served for that , and [he]451-a man lay panting on the ground . “[628-many foes] Oh , do let ’s go [home]357-home ! ” said [Jane]134-jane . “[628-many foes] Look here — [I]0-i do n’t care — [I]0-i will ! ” [She]134-jane held up the charm . Fortunately all [the strange , fair people]2594-the strange , fair people were too busy to notice [her]134-jane . [She]134-jane held up the charm . And nothing happened . “[134-jane] [You]134-jane have n’t said the word of power , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . [Jane]134-jane hastily said it — and still nothing happened . “[134-jane] Hold it up towards [the East]32-the east , [you]134-jane silly ! ” said [Robert]132-robert . “[134-jane] Which is [the East]32-the east ? ” said [Jane]134-jane , dancing about in [her]134-jane agony of terror . [Nobody]2255-nobody knew . So [they]630-we opened the fish‐bag to ask [the Psammead]136-the psammead . And the bag had only a waterproof sheet in it . [The Psammead]136-the psammead was gone . “[134-jane] Hide the sacred thing ! Hide it ! Hide it ! ” whispered [the girl]2486-the girl . [Cyril]131-cyril shrugged [his]131-cyril shoulders , and tried to look as brave as [he]131-cyril knew [he]131-cyril ought to feel . “[134-jane] Hide it up , [Pussy]155-pussy , ” [he]131-cyril said . “[155-pussy] [We]630-we are in for it now . [We]630-we ’ve just got to stay and see it out . ” [HERE]2247-here was a horrible position ! [Four English children , whose proper date was A.D. 1905 , and whose proper address was [London]2-london , set down in [Egypt]21-egypt in the year 6000 B.C. , with no means whatever of getting back into [their]2598-four english children , whose proper date was a.d. 1905 , and whose proper address was london , set down in egypt in the year 6000 b.c. , with no means whatever of getting back into their own time and place own time and place]2598-four english children , whose proper date was a.d. 1905 , and whose proper address was london , set down in egypt in the year 6000 b.c. , with no means whatever of getting back into their own time and place . [They]2598-four english children , whose proper date was a.d. 1905 , and whose proper address was london , set down in egypt in the year 6000 b.c. , with no means whatever of getting back into their own time and place could not find [the East]32-the east , and the sun was of no use at the moment , because [some officious person]2599-some officious person had once explained to [Cyril]131-cyril that the sun did not really set in [the West]33-the west at all — nor rise in [the East]32-the east either , for the matter of that . [The Psammead]136-the psammead had crept out of the bass‐bag when [they]2598-four english children , whose proper date was a.d. 1905 , and whose proper address was london , set down in egypt in the year 6000 b.c. , with no means whatever of getting back into their own time and place were not looking and had basely deserted [them]2598-four english children , whose proper date was a.d. 1905 , and whose proper address was london , set down in egypt in the year 6000 b.c. , with no means whatever of getting back into their own time and place . [An enemy]2600-an enemy was approaching . There would be a fight . [People]280-people get killed in fights , and the idea of taking part in a fight was one that did not smile to [the children]278-the children . [The man who had brought the news of the enemy]2603-the man who had brought the news of the enemy still lay panting on [the sand]279-the sand . [His]2603-the man who had brought the news of the enemy tongue was hanging out , long and red , like a dog ’s . [The people of [the village]2522-the village]2605-the people of the village were hur‐ riedly filling the gaps in the fence with thorn‐bushes from the heap that seemed to have been piled there ready for just such a need . [They]2605-the people of the village lifted the clustering thorns with long poles — much as [[men]2526-men at [home]357-home]2608-men at home , nowadays , lift hay with a fork . [Jane]134-jane bit [her]134-jane lip and tried to decide not to cry . [Robert]132-robert felt in [his]132-robert pocket for a toy pistol and loaded it with a pink paper cap . It was [his]132-robert only weapon . [Cyril]131-cyril tightened [his]131-cyril belt two holes . And [Anthea]133-anthea absently took the drooping red roses from the buttonholes of the others , bit the ends of the stalks , and set them in a pot of water that stood in the shadow by a hut door . [She]133-anthea was always rather silly about flowers . “[134-jane] Look here ! ” [she]133-anthea said . “[134-jane] [I]0-i think perhaps [the Psammead]400-the psammead is really arranging something for [us]632-us . [I]0-i do n’t believe it would go away and leave [us]632-us all alone in [the Past]20-the past . [I]0-i ’m certain it would n’t . ” [Jane]134-jane succeeded in deciding not to cry — at any rate yet . “[0-i] But what can [we]632-us do ? ” [Robert]132-robert asked . “[0-i] Nothing , ” [Cyril]131-cyril answered promptly , “[0-i] except keep [our]632-us eyes and ears open . Look ! [That runner chap ’s getting [his]633-that runner chap ’s getting his wind wind]633-that runner chap ’s getting his wind . Let ’s go and hear what [he]633-that runner chap ’s getting his wind ’s got to say . ” [The runner]2610-the runner had risen to [his]2610-the runner knees and was sitting back on [his]2610-the runner heels . Now [he]2610-the runner stood up and spoke . [He]2610-the runner began by some respectful remarks addressed to [the heads of [the village]2522-the village]2611-the heads of the village . [His]2610-the runner speech got more interesting when [he]2610-the runner said — “[0-i] [I]0-i went out in [my]0-i raft to snare ibises , and [I]0-i had gone up [the stream]2476-the stream an hour ’s journey . Then [I]0-i set [my]0-i snares and waited . And [I]0-i heard the sound of many wings , and looking up , saw many herons circling in the air . And [I]0-i saw that [they]635-they were afraid ; so [I]0-i took thought . A beast may scare one heron , coming upon it suddenly , but no beast will scare a whole flock of herons . And still [they]635-they flew and circled , and would not alight . So then [I]0-i knew that what scared [the herons]636-the herons must be [men]2526-men , and [men who knew not [our]639-we ways of going softly so as to take the birds and beasts unawares]638-men who knew not our ways of going softly so as to take the birds and beasts unawares . By this [I]0-i knew [they]635-they were not of [our]639-we race or of [our]639-we place . So , leaving [[my]0-i raft]640-my raft , [I]0-i crept along [the river bank]641-the river bank , and at last came upon [the strangers]642-the strangers . [They]642-the strangers are many as [the sands of [the desert]553-the desert]643-the sands of the desert , and [their]642-the strangers spear‐heads shine red like the sun . [They]642-the strangers are [a terrible people]645-a terrible people , and [their]642-the strangers march is towards [us]639-we . Having seen this , [I]0-i ran , and did not stay till [I]0-i was before [you]646-you . ” “[0-i] [These]642-the strangers are [[your]646-you folk]647-your folk , ” said [the headman]2613-the headman , turning suddenly and angrily on [Cyril]131-cyril , “[646-you] [you]646-you came as [spies]648-spies for [them]642-the strangers . ” “[646-you] [We]639-we did not , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril indignantly . “[646-you] [We]639-we would n’t be [spies]648-spies for anything . [I]0-i ’m certain [these people]2543-these people are n’t a bit like [us]639-we . Are [they]2543-these people now ? ” [he]0-i asked [the runner]2610-the runner . “[2543-these people] No , ” was the answer . “[2543-these people] [these men]651-these men ’s faces were darkened , and [their]651-these men hair black as night . Yet [these strange children]652-these strange children , maybe , are [[their]651-these men gods]653-their gods , who have come before to make ready the way for [them]651-these men . ” A murmur ran through [the crowd]2541-the crowd . “[652-these strange children] No , no , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril again . “[652-these strange children] [We]639-we are on [your]654-your side . [We]639-we will help [you]654-your to guard [your]654-your sacred things . ” [The headman]2613-the headman seemed impressed by the fact that [Cyril]131-cyril knew that there were sacred things to be guarded . [He]131-cyril stood a moment gazing at [the children]278-the children . Then [he]131-cyril said — “[639-we] It is well . And now let [all]655-all make offering , that [we]655-all may be strong in battle . ” [The crowd]2541-the crowd dispersed , and [nine men]2619-nine men , wearing antelope‐skins , grouped [themselves]2619-nine men in front of the opening in the hedge in [the middle of [the village]2522-the village]2521-the middle of the village . And presently , one by one , [the men]615-the men brought all sorts of things — hippopotamus flesh , ostrich‐feathers , the fruit of the date palms , red chalk , green chalk , fish from [the river]2467-the river , and ibex from [the mountains]2624-the mountains ; and [the headman]2613-the headman received these gifts . There was another hedge inside the first , about a yard from [it]2626-it , so that there was a lane inside between the hedges . And every now and then [one of [the headmen]2628-the headmen]2627-one of the headmen would disappear along [this lane]2629-this lane with full hands and come back with hands empty . “[656-they] [They]656-they ’re making offerings to [their]656-they Amulet , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[656-they] [We]655-all ’d better give something too . ” The pockets of [the party]2630-the party , hastily explored , yielded a piece of pink tape , a bit of sealing‐ wax , and part of the [Waterbury]34-waterbury watch that [Robert]132-robert had not been able to help taking to pieces at Christmas and had never had time to rearrange . [Most boys]2631-most boys have a watch in this condition . [They]2631-most boys presented [their]2631-most boys offerings , and [Anthea]133-anthea added the red roses . [The headman who took the things]2632-the headman who took the things looked at [them]2631-most boys with awe , especially at the red roses and the Waterbury‐watch fragment . “[656-they] This is a day of very wondrous happenings , ” [he]0-i said . “[0-i] [I]0-i have no more room in [me]0-i to be astonished . [[Our]655-all maiden]657-our maiden said there was peace between [you]658-you and [us]655-all . But for this coming of [a foe]659-a foe [we]655-all should have made sure . ” [The children]278-the children shuddered . “[657-our maiden] Now speak . Are [you]0-i upon [our]655-all side ? ” “[0-i] Yes . Do n’t [I]0-i keep telling [you]0-i [we]655-all are ? ” [Robert]132-robert said . “[0-i] Look here . [I]0-i will give [you]0-i a sign . [You]0-i see this . ” [He]0-i held out the toy pistol . “[0-i] [I]0-i shall speak to it , and if it answers [me]0-i [you]0-i will know that [I]0-i and [the others]325-the others are come to guard [your]0-i sacred thing — that [we]655-all ’ve just made the offerings to . ” “[0-i] Will [that god whose image [you]0-i hold in [your]0-i hand]661-that god whose image you hold in your hand speak to [you]0-i alone , or shall [I]0-i also hear it ? ” asked [the man]2282-the man cautiously . “[0-i] [You]0-i ’ll be surprised when [you]0-i do hear it , ” said [Robert]132-robert . “[0-i] Now , then . ” [He]132-robert looked at the pistol and said — “[0-i] If [we]655-all are to guard the sacred treasure within”—he pointed to the hedged‐in space—“speak[0-i] with [thy]0-i loud voice , and [we]655-all shall obey . ” [He]132-robert pulled the trigger , and the cap went off . The noise was loud , for it was a two‐shilling pistol , and the caps were excellent . [Every man]2635-every man , [woman]2636-woman , and child in [the village]2522-the village fell on its face on [the sand]279-the sand . [The headman who had accepted the test]2639-the headman who had accepted the test rose first . “[2425-the voice] [The voice]2425-the voice has spoken , ” [he]132-robert said . “[2425-the voice] Lead [them]663-them into [the ante‐room of the sacred thing]664-the ante‐room of the sacred thing . ” So now [the four children]309-the four children were led in through the opening of the hedge and round [the lane]339-the lane till [they]309-the four children came to an opening in the inner hedge , and [they]309-the four children went through an opening in that , and so passed into [another lane]2642-another lane . [The thing]2643-the thing was built something like this , and all the hedges were of brushwood and thorns : “[2425-the voice] It ’s like [the maze at [Hampton Court]35-hampton court]665-the maze at hampton court , ” whispered [Anthea]133-anthea . [The lanes]2644-the lanes were all open to the sky , but [the little hut in the middle of [the maze]2646-the maze]2645-the little hut in the middle of the maze was round‐roofed , and a curtain of skins hung over the doorway . “[2425-the voice] [Here]2247-here [you]663-them may wait , ” said [[their]309-the four children guide]2647-their guide , “[663-them] but do not dare to pass the curtain . ” [He]2647-their guide himself passed [it]2648-it and disappeared . “[2425-the voice] But look here , ” whispered [Cyril]131-cyril , “[2425-the voice] [some of [us]668-we]667-some of us ought to be outside , in case [the Psammead]136-the psammead turns up . ” “[2425-the voice] Do n’t let ’s get separated from [each other]312-each other , whatever [we]668-we do , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[2425-the voice] It ’s quite bad enough to be separated from [the Psammead]136-the psammead . [We]668-we ca n’t do anything while [that man]431-that man is in [there]321-there . Let ’s all go out into [the village]2522-the village again . [We]668-we can come back later now [we]668-we know the way in . [That man’ll]673-that man’ll have to fight like the rest , most likely , if it comes to fighting . If [we]668-we find [the Psammead]136-the psammead [we]668-we ’ll go straight [home]357-home . It must be getting late , and [I]0-i do n’t much like [this mazy place]675-this mazy place . ” [They]668-we went out and told [the headman]2613-the headman that [they]668-we would protect the treasure when the fighting began . And now [they]668-we looked about [them]668-we and were able to see exactly how [a first‐class worker]2650-a first‐class worker in flint flakes and notches an arrow‐head or the edge of an axe — an advantage which [no other person now alive]2651-no other person now alive has ever enjoyed . [The boys]313-the boys found the weapons most interesting . The arrow‐heads were not on arrows such as [you]2653-you shoot from a bow , but on javelins , for throwing from the hand . The chief weapon was a stone fastened to a rather short stick something like the things [gentlemen]2654-gentlemen used to carry about and call [life‐preservers]2655-life‐preservers in the days of the garrotters . Then there were long things like spears or lances , with flint heads to them , and there were flint knives — horribly sharp — and flint battle‐axes . [Everyone in [the village]2522-the village]2656-everyone in the village was so busy that [the place]539-the place was like an ant‐heap when [you]2653-you have walked into [it]539-the place by accident . [The women]2547-the women were busy and even [the children]278-the children . Quite suddenly all the air seemed to glow and grow red — it was like the sudden opening of a furnace door , such as [you]2653-you may see at [Woolwich Arsenal]36-woolwich arsenal if [you]2653-you ever have the luck to be taken [there]321-there — and then almost as suddenly it was as though the furnace doors had been shut . For the sun had set , and it was night . The sun had that abrupt way of setting in [Egypt]21-egypt eight thousand years ago , and [I]624-my father believe it has never been able to break itself of the habit , and sets in exactly the same manner to the present day . [The girl]2486-the girl brought the skins of wild deer and led [the children]278-the children to a heap of dry sedge . “[624-my father] [[My]0-i father]624-my father says [they]677-they will not attack yet . Sleep ! ” [she]2486-the girl said , and it really seemed a good idea . [You]2653-you may think that in the midst of all these dangers [the children]278-the children would not have been able to sleep — but somehow , though [they]278-the children were rather frightened now and then , the feeling was growing in [them]278-the children — deep down and almost hidden away , but still growing — that [the Psammead]136-the psammead was to be trusted , and that [they]278-the children were really and truly safe . This did not prevent [their]278-the children being quite as much frightened as [they]278-the children could bear to be without being perfectly miserable . “[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [we]678-us ’d better go to sleep , ” said [Robert]132-robert . “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know what [on earth]679-on earth [poor old Nurse]142-old nurse will do with [us]678-us out all night ; set [the police]680-the police on [our]678-us tracks , [I]0-i expect . [I]0-i only wish [they]680-the police could find [us]678-us ! [A dozen policemen]681-a dozen policemen would be rather welcome just now . But it ’s no use getting into a stew over it , ” [he]0-i added soothingly . “[682-the strange men] Good night . ” And [they]278-the children all fell asleep . [They]278-the children were awakened by long , loud , terrible sounds that seemed to come from everywhere at once — horrible threatening shouts and shrieks and howls that sounded , as [Cyril]131-cyril said later , like the voices of [men]2526-men thirsting for [[their]2526-men enemies]2666-their enemies ’ blood . “[682-the strange men] It is the voice of [the strange men]682-the strange men , ” said [the girl]2486-the girl , coming to [them]278-the children trembling through the dark . “[682-the strange men] [They]682-the strange men have attacked the walls , and the thorns have driven [them]682-the strange men back . [[My]0-i father]624-my father says [they]682-the strange men will not try again till daylight . But [they]682-the strange men are shouting to frighten [us]678-us . As though [we]678-us were [savages]684-savages ! dwellers in [the swamps]685-the swamps ! ” [she]2486-the girl said indignantly . All night the terrible noise went on , but when the sun rose , as abruptly as [he]131-cyril had set , the sound suddenly ceased . [The children]278-the children had hardly time to be glad of this before a shower of javelins came hurtling over the great thorn‐hedge , and [everyone]319-everyone sheltered behind [the huts]2529-the huts . But next moment another shower of weapons came from the opposite side , and [the crowd]2541-the crowd rushed to other shelter . [Cyril]131-cyril pulled out a javelin that had stuck in the roof of [the hut beside [him]131-cyril]2672-the hut beside him . Its head was of brightly burnished copper . Then the sound of shouting arose again and the crackle of dried thorns . [The enemy]2673-the enemy was breaking down the hedge . [All the villagers]2674-all the villagers swarmed to the point whence the crackling and the shouting came ; [they]2674-all the villagers hurled stones over the hedges , and short arrows with flint heads . [The children]278-the children had never before seen [men]2526-men with the fighting light in [their]2526-men eyes . It was very strange and terrible , and gave [you]2677-you a queer thick feeling in [your]2677-you throat ; it was quite different from the pictures of fights in the illustrated papers at [home]357-home . It seemed that the shower of stones had driven back [the besiegers]2679-the besiegers . [The besieged]2680-the besieged drew breath , but at that moment the shouting and the crackling arose on [the opposite side of [the village]2522-the village]2681-the opposite side of the village and [the crowd]2541-the crowd hastened to defend that point , and so the fight swayed to and fro across [the village]2522-the village , for [the besieged]2680-the besieged had not the sense to divide [their]2680-the besieged forces as [[their]2680-the besieged enemies]2666-their enemies had done . [Cyril]131-cyril noticed that every now and then [certain of [the fighting‐men]2688-the fighting‐men]2687-certain of the fighting‐men would enter [the maze]2646-the maze , and come out with brighter faces , a braver aspect , and [a more upright carriage]2690-a more upright carriage . “[682-the strange men] [I]0-i believe [they]686-they go and touch the Amulet , ” [he]131-cyril said . “[686-they] [You]687-you know [the Psammead]136-the psammead said it could make [people]280-people brave . ” [They]686-they crept through [the maze]2646-the maze , and watching [they]686-they saw that [Cyril]131-cyril was right . [A headman]2692-a headman was standing in front of the skin curtain , and as [the warriors]2693-the warriors came before [him]2692-a headman [he]2692-a headman murmured a word [they]2693-the warriors could not hear , and touched [their]2693-the warriors foreheads with something that [they]2693-the warriors could not see . And this something [he]2692-a headman held in [his]2692-a headman hands . And through [his]2692-a headman fingers [they]2693-the warriors saw the gleam of a red stone that [they]2693-the warriors knew . The fight raged across [the thorn‐hedge outside]2694-the thorn‐hedge outside . Suddenly there was a loud and bitter cry . “[136-the psammead] [They]689-they ’re in ! [They]689-they ’re in ! The hedge is down ! ” [The headman]2613-the headman disappeared behind the deer‐skin curtain . “[690-he] [He]690-he ’s gone to hide it , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[690-he] Oh , [Psammead]136-the psammead dear , how could [you]136-the psammead leave [us]691-us ! ” Suddenly there was a shriek from inside [the hut]2696-the hut , and [the headman]2613-the headman staggered out white with fear and fled out through [the maze]2646-the maze . [The children]278-the children were as white as [he]2613-the headman . “[136-the psammead] Oh ! what is it ? what is it ? ” moaned [Anthea]133-anthea . “[136-the psammead] Oh , [Psammead]136-the psammead , how could [you]136-the psammead ! how could [you]136-the psammead ! ” And the sound of the fight sank breathlessly , and swelled fiercely all around . It was like the rising and falling of the waves of [the sea]2414-the sea . [Anthea]133-anthea shuddered and said again , “[136-the psammead] Oh , [Psammead]136-the psammead , [Psammead]136-the psammead ! ” “[136-the psammead] Well ? ” said a brisk voice , and the curtain of skins was lifted at one corner by a furry hand , and out peeped the bat ’s ears and snail ’s eyes of [the Psammead]136-the psammead . [Anthea]133-anthea caught it in [her]133-anthea arms and a sigh of desperate relief was breathed by each of the four . “[136-the psammead] Oh ! which is [the East]32-the east ! ” [Anthea]133-anthea said , and [she]133-anthea spoke hurriedly , for the noise of wild fighting drew nearer and nearer . “[136-the psammead] Do n’t choke [me]0-i , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead , “[136-the psammead] come inside . ” The inside of [the hut]2696-the hut was pitch dark . “[136-the psammead] [I]0-i ’ve got a match , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , and struck it . The floor of [the hut]2696-the hut was of soft , loose sand . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ve been asleep here , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead ; “[136-the psammead] most comfortable it ’s been , the best sand [I]0-i ’ve had for a month . It ’s all right . Everything ’s all right . [I]0-i knew [your]692-you only chance would be while the fight was going on . [That man]431-that man wo n’t come back . [I]0-i bit [him]431-that man , and [he]431-that man thinks [I]0-i ’m [an Evil Spirit]694-an evil spirit . Now [you]692-you ’ve only got to take the thing and go . ” [The hut]2696-the hut was hung with skins . Heaped in the middle were the offerings that had been given the night before , [Anthea]133-anthea ’s roses fading on the top of the heap . At one side of [the hut]2696-the hut stood a large square stone block , and on it an oblong box of earthenware with strange figures of [men]2526-men and beasts on it . “[692-you] Is the thing in there ? ” asked [Cyril]131-cyril , as [the Psammead]400-the psammead pointed a skinny finger at it . “[692-you] [You]692-you must judge of that , ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead . “[692-you] [The man]2282-the man was just going to bury the box in the sand when [I]0-i jumped out at [him]431-that man and bit [him]431-that man . ” “[0-i] Light another match , [Robert]132-robert , ” said [Anthea]133-anthea . “[132-robert] Now , then quick ! which is [the East]32-the east ? ” “[132-robert] Why , where the sun rises , of course ! ” “[132-robert] But [someone]331-someone told [us]697-us — ” “[331-someone] Oh ! [they]331-someone ’ll tell [you]692-you anything ! ” said [the Psammead]136-the psammead impatiently , getting into its bass‐bag and wrapping itself in its waterproof sheet . “[331-someone] But [we]697-us ca n’t see the sun in here , and it is n’t rising anyhow , ” said [Jane]134-jane . “[697-us] How [you]692-you do waste time ! ” [the Psammead]136-the psammead said . “[692-you] Why , [the East]32-the east ’s where [the shrine]550-the shrine is , of course . There ! ” [It]136-the psammead pointed to the great stone . And still the shouting and the clash of stone on metal sounded nearer and nearer . [The children]278-the children could hear that [the headmen]2628-the headmen had surrounded [the hut]2696-the hut to protect [their]2628-the headmen treasure as long as might be from [the enemy]2673-the enemy . But [none]625-none dared to come in after [the Psammead]136-the psammead ’s sudden fierce biting of [the headman]2613-the headman . “[697-us] Now , [Jane]134-jane , ” said [Cyril]131-cyril , very quickly . “[134-jane] [I]0-i ’ll take the Amulet , [you]692-you stand ready to hold up the charm , and be sure [you]692-you do n’t let it go as [you]692-you come through . ” [He]0-i made a step forward , but at that instant a great crackling overhead ended in a blaze of sunlight . The roof had been broken in at one side , and great slabs of it were being lifted off by two spears . As [the children]278-the children trembled and winked in the new light , large dark hands tore down the wall , and [a dark face , with a blobby fat nose]2714-a dark face , with a blobby fat nose , looked over the gap .
